title: Love heals all wounds (so they say)
fandoms: Star Wars Legends: Jedi Apprentice Series - Jude Watson & Dave Wolverton
Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008) - All Media Types
additional_tags: Obi-Wan is a healer and this changes his path
Obi-Wan and Anakin have a healthier relationship than in canon
Obi-Wan does not take Anakin as his padawan
References to Star Wars: The Clone Wars (2008)
summary:
Vokara speaks before he can. “I didn’t come here for your permission. I don’t need it. I am a Master Healer, and it is my right to take an apprentice.”

“And you want Obi-Wan Kenobi?” Mace Windu asks.

“Yes,” Vokara answers.

 

Or, Obi-Wan is wanted, becomes a healer, and this changes everything.
notes:
This is a story about the power of love and healing because I am, at my core, deeply predictable. It began as a 5+1 on the different people who could have trained Obi-Wan and then became an entire story in its own right. Because, again, predictable.

Fanfiction is a fun way to explore new things and so I've done something new (to me) with the story and it's told from different points of view. Each chapter title will name the POV character. It's an exploration of Obi-Wan mostly from other people's perceptions of him. Which means it's far kinder to him than a story told from his own perspective (Exhibit A: Can't return to who I was before).

(See the end of the work for other works inspired by this one.)

Melida/Daan time! It happens differently than in canon, but canon warnings apply (violence, child soldiers, child death - not of this is explicit)

POV is Anakin so warnings for child slavery and the abuses which come with it. Nothing explicit but the undercurrents are there.

And so the Clone Wars begin : )

Vod/vode - sibling (siblings) / sister (sisters) / brother (brothers)
Verd/verde - soldier (soldiers)
Baar'ur - medic

It's Fizz's time! I have to say, I really enjoy the symmetry of the final chapters which go Cody-Rex-Fizz-Rex-Cody.

Well...here we are. Thank you to everyone who has come on this journey with me. I hope you've enjoyed reading this story as much as I've enjoyed writing it.
text:
Vokara Che enters the Council Chambers in time to hear Master Yoda say, “Send him away, we must. A break from precedent, it is, but necessary, it also is.”

It doesn’t take a genius to know who Master Yoda refers to; though, as a Master Healer, Vokara Che is an intelligent woman. The Temple gossip mill churns, as it always does, and it appears that everyone, from the padawans to the knights to even the councilors are discussing the two initiates who wound up in Vokara’s domain.

“It isn’t necessary,” Vokara says, announcing her presence and her opinion at the same time. Her fellow Jedi greet her with a mix of irritation for the interruption and respect for her position.

“By Initiate Chun’s account, Initiate Kenobi attacked him from a place of anger and a misguided belief that besting him would prove his worth to a Jedi Master.” Mace Windu speaks evenly, with the measured calm which makes him a good councilor.

“And by Initiate Kenobi’s account?” Vokara asks.

Master Dooku laughs quietly from his chair. “Why bother with the account of the accused when their fate is already decided?” His derision is pointed, and even though he doesn’t look toward his former master, Master Yoda’s ears flatten against his head with the censure.

“He is dangerous,” Master Droom says. He’s a recent addition to the Council, and it doesn’t surprise Vokara that he sides with Master Yoda.

“We’re all dangerous,” Vokara says. “It’s why the Jedi Order places an emphasis on control. I’ve spoken with Initiate Kenobi.”

“So have we,” Master Droom interrupts. “He did not defend himself.”

“You hauled a scared child in front of the most austere council in the galaxy. I’m surprised he remembered his name.” Vokara gives Master Droom a sharp look, warning him against further interruptions.

“Initiate Chun’s wounds and Initiate Kenobi’s lack of them corroborate Initiate Chun’s account,” Mace says.

“And none of you thought to consult their healer?” Vokara’s sharp look is now directed at Mace. She has the sense he wants her to speak her opinion, that he’s guiding her to her conclusion. “Initiate Chun does bear the marks of a fight. But so does Initiate Kenobi. It was unsanctioned, and neither of their actions befitted that of a Jedi, but it was not as one-sided as Initiate Chun would have you believe.”

“We saw Initiate Kenobi with our own eyes!” Master Droom says.

Once, a well-meaning colleague told Vokara that instead of seduction, the Twi’lek gods gave her twice the sass. It’s true, she doesn’t have the allure that most of her species do, but it isn’t something she ever cultivated. She is brisk, she is businesslike, and she doesn’t put up with stupidity.

The glare she directs at Master Droom suggests he not speak for the rest of this meeting. “Did you look with more than your eyes?” It was obvious they didn’t. “Initiate Kenobi, through basic healing skills, some bandages, and a judicious amount of notice-me-not, successfully hid his own wounds from the fight.”

“Healing skills?” Mace asks.

“Notice-me-not?” Master Dooku asks.

“I am making an offer to Initiate Kenobi,” Vokara says, finally getting to why she came here. “If he accepts, I will train him.”

Chaos breaks out for a moment as everyone shouts to be heard over each other. There are protests. There are concerns. There are outright refusals. Master Yoda knocks his stick against the ground. Three loud raps and the room falls silent.

Vokara speaks before he can. “I didn’t come here for your permission. I don’t need it. I am a Master Healer, and it is my right to take an apprentice.”

“And you want Obi-Wan Kenobi?” Master Windu asks.

“Yes,” Vokara answers.

 

#

Vokara returns to the Halls of Healing after her meeting with the Council. She has duties to attend to and as much as she wants to find Obi-Wan and make her offer, there are things which must come first.

It isn’t until there’s a knock at her door that she wonders if delaying only gave others a chance to intervene. She looks at Mace and his offering of agaricum. He doesn’t waver under her sharp stare. She sighs and waves him in. She takes the plate, because she is hungry, but she won’t be bribed or distracted.

“I’m making my offer,” she tells him.

“I know. I’m not here to talk you out of it.” Mace sits near the air vent, and Vokara can’t help her smile. Agaricum is a Twi’lek dish. Most sentients find the pungent odor unpleasant. “Master Yoda said he had a plan for Obi-Wan. He wasn’t going to be left in the AgriCorps.”

“But he was still being sent there?” Vokara shakes her head. Mace’s silence is answer enough. “Obi-Wan was going to be told he isn’t good enough, punished for being a failure, and then sent away so he could fall into Master Yoda’s plan?” She shakes her head again. “What do you know about Obi-Wan Kenobi?”

Mace frowns as if he doesn’t understand why Vokara is asking. He leans back in his chair, thinking, and she gives him the time to gather his response. “He is a near-human, actual species unknown. He was left on the Temple steps as an infant. He was raised in the Temple and has shown promise in lightsaber combat. Recently, he’s become anxious and withdrawn. And most recently, he engaged in an unsanctioned fight which was supposed to result in his early release from the Temple.”

“Early release? Such a diplomat’s way of putting it.”

Mace raises his eyebrows. “What would you call it?”

“Rejection. Expulsion.” Vokara shrugs her shoulders. Both are harsh words and while Mace’s expression suggests he believes them to be too harsh, she doesn’t.

“Not all initiates are good fits to continue their path at the Temple,” Mace says. “We aren’t rejecting them. We’re guiding them toward the correct path.”

“Except you said it isn’t an issue of Initiate Kenobi being unfit, it’s part of a plan Master Yoda has.” Vokara taps her fork on her plate. “He has harmed Initiate Kenobi. You say he has a reason for it. I don’t care. Initiate Kenobi is a child, not a pawn.”

Mace takes a deep breath, but it isn’t to marshal an argument. He looks tired, afterward. “You’re correct. Master Yoda’s age gives wisdom and insight into history, but it also sets him in his ways. He sees from a distance we don’t.”

“It’s our role to offer our insights and challenge him when necessary,” Vokara says. “Our Order is only as strong as those who lead it.”

“I am grateful for your voice,” Mace says.

“And my willingness to use it?” Vokara smiles sharply. “You know my opinions on raising younglings. They should be surrounded by younglings similar in developmental age and guided by a diverse group of adults.” She gives Mace a significant look.

He meets it with an amused smile. He draws out the silence until Vokara starts tapping her fork again. “Are you asking me to help you train Initiate Kenobi?”

“Yes. You’ll be a positive influence in his life.”

Vokara is a medical professional which is why she spots the way Mace’s fingers twitch as if he wants to touch his face and hide his embarrassment. “It’s a compliment, Mace. You can’t be that out of practice with receiving them.”

He gives in and laughs, a deep, rich sound. Vokara knows it is the right choice to offer to train Initiate Kenobi, but now she knows there are other Jedi who she can count on for support.

#

There is a rumor that the healers live in the Halls of Healing which is ridiculous. They work in shifts, and they are discouraged from spending two shifts in the Halls and outright forbidden from three in a row. There is always work to be done but burning oneself out helps no one.

After her shift, Vokara goes to the Room of a Thousand Fountains, a place she heard Initiate Kenobi visits with great frequency. It takes her some time to find him inside the vast room. He isn’t by the waterfall as many of the younglings prefer. He isn’t amongst the citrus groves. He isn’t with the flowers or the most impressive of the fountains.

He’s tucked out of the way, meditating by a shallow pond. Vokara sees flashes of color as the fish dart about in the water. She clears her throat and it’s enough to draw Initiate Kenobi out of his meditation.

His arms are covered by his tunics so she can’t check on the progress of his injuries. She can see his face, though, and because she knows to look for it, she sees the shadow of bruises where he tries to project unblemished skin. He is quiet under her scrutiny, but his eyes widen just a bit as if he’s afraid. He draws his shoulders up as if preparing to defend himself.

“It’s peaceful here,” Vokara says. She sweeps her robes aside as she kneels on the grass.

“It is,” Initiate Kenobi agrees. He dips his fingers in the water and smiles as the fish mouth at his skin, curious at what’s in their water. “I’ll miss it.”

“And why is that?”

“My transport for the AgriCorps leaves tomorrow,” Initiate Kenobi answers. His chin wobbles, but his voice doesn’t.

“The AgriCorps only accepts initiates,” Vokara says. “And if you would like to explore that path, I will not stand in your way. But I will offer you a second path. Would you like to be my padawan and learn the Jedi art of healing?”

Blue-gray eyes study her as if searching for any sign that this is a lie or a joke. “Is this a true offer?”

“It is,” Vokara promises. And then she answers the question he’s too hesitant to ask. “You sped along your own healing which is something many Jedi can’t do even with training. No one had flagged your file to indicate your potential for healing so I didn’t observe you as closely as I should have. But I have noticed you now, and you are an initiate I would be proud to call padawan.”

Initiate Kenobi’s eyes fill with hope. His expression is almost bright enough to be painful or perhaps that is pain Vokara feels, an ache in her chest at what might never have been. “It isn’t an easy path. You will see the galaxy’s suffering and its pain, and you’ll never be able to help as much as you would like to. But you will help, just as all healers do.”

“Please,” Initiate Kenobi says and Vokara doesn’t understand how anyone thought he has an aggressive bone in his body. “I would like to be your padawan and learn from you.”

#

Vokara has enrolled Obi-Wan in several healing modules to supplement his course load. They are all basic courses in healing, in physiology, in biology, and even chemistry. There will be advanced courses to do as he completes his basic ones. It’s an overwhelming amount of information to consider which is why Vokara limits his understanding of the scope.

Healers, like Archivists, are required to hold an incredible amount of information in their heads at one time.

In addition to more classes, Obi-Wan also spends a quarter-shift each day in the Halls of Healing. Right now, she has him shadow Healer Nikita so he learns the layout, how to organize the storeroom and sterilize the equipment. It’s to acclimate him to the Halls which are a place where the Force is different.

Not everyone can be a healer and not only because of ability.

It’s something deeper. To stand in the Halls of Healing is to stand inside a concerted distortion of the Force. The Force gives and the Force takes, but healers seek to reverse the course of life or speed up a natural healing process. They shape the Force to their needs, and it leaves some with shaking hands or numb mouths or buzzing heads.

Obi-Wan hasn’t shown any ill-effects for his time in the Halls. He fetches supplies without complaint, he cleans instruments thoroughly, and he stares longingly when one of the healers attends to a patient as if he wants to do more.

Vokara doesn’t make him wait long.

The Temple runs a clinic for any who need their services. No one is turned away, regardless of their ident, or lack of it, or their ability to pay.

Today, Vokara’s patient is a young humanoid girl with red eyes and a hacking cough. She sits on the table and swings her feet as Vokara and Obi-Wan approach.

“I am Healer Che,” Vokara introduces. “And this is my padawan, Obi-Wan.”

Obi-Wan wiggles his fingers in hello.

“I’m Sharice,” the girl says.

The girl’s guardian, who sits in the chair by the door, shifts nervously as they look Obi-Wan over.

“Padawan means that Obi-Wan is my apprentice,” Vokara tells Sharice. “He’s learning to be a healer as well. He’s going to sit over there,” Vokara points to a meditation mat, “and he’s going to see what I see while I help you. But I’m the one who is going to treat you.”

“Okay.” Sharice keeps swinging her legs, but her guardian relaxes once they realize their child isn’t being treated by a trainee.

Vokara waits until Obi-Wan is seated and she can feel him slide through their bond to begin her examination. Obi-Wan hovers in the back of her mind, undeniably there, but only a visitor. He can see what she sees, can feel what she feels, and he can communicate with Vokara. It’s the perfect training tool. He can have the full experience without any of the responsibility.

“Lie down for me, please,” Vokara tells Sharice. “I’m going to do a scan.” She picks up her medical scanner and explains the settings to Obi-Wan as she selects the one she wants. She guides the scanner over Sharice’s body. She lingers on the eyes, ears, throat, and chest.

The scanner processes the information it received and then creates a report. It identifies the symptoms, and it offers probable ailments based on numerous factors. Unfortunately for Sharice, the most likely cause of her symptoms isn’t curable but it is treatable.

“You are allergic to smog,” Vokara says. “Do you know what smog is?”

“Pollution,” Sharice answers.

“Yes. The exhaust from all the vehicles in Coruscant irritates your throat and lungs. The best thing is fresh, clean air, but the second-best thing is antihistamines. I can give you a dose now. You’ll need a monthly dose. You can make an appointment with our scheduling droid when we’re finished today.”

Vokara opens the cabinet with the common medications, the ones which don’t need to be locked up. She selects the standard antihistamine, fills her hypospray with the correct amount for Sharice’s age and species and then walks back to her patient.

Sharice’s wide brown eyes look at the needle with alarm.

“It’s okay.”

Vokara hadn’t noticed Obi-Wan slipping out of their bond, but he did because he’s now standing next to her. He offers Sharice a smile and then one of his hands. “You can hold my hand.”

Sharice, still looking at the needle, slips her small hand into Obi-Wan’s equally small one.

“I like your dress,” Obi-Wan says.

Sharice looks down at the garment. It’s a multi-colored block dress which reminds Vokara more of an initiate’s painting project than fashion, but Sharice blushes with the compliment. She tugs at one of the tassels on her dress. “Thank you. My aunt made it for me. She said I should wear it when I miss her. She’s still on Brenli. That’s where we used to live.”

Vokara waits until Sharice is absorbed in her conversation with Obi-Wan to inject her with the hypospray. It’s barely even a pinch, and Sharice doesn’t notice it, too busy telling Obi-Wan about a snowball fight she had with her cousins before she and her mom moved to Coruscant to live with her dad.

“Do you like snow?” Sharice asks.

“It doesn’t snow on Coruscant,” Obi-Wan answers. “So I don’t know yet. Healer Che gave you your shot.”

“Really?” Sharice twists to look at her arm. “That didn’t even hurt!”

“I’m glad,” Vokara says. To both Sharice and her guardian, she says, “You’re all set. Don’t forget to make your follow-up appointment.”

“And you get one of these!” Obi-Wan uses the Force to call the jar of lollipops to him. He holds the jar out to Sharice.

She picks through it until she finds a rainbow-colored lollipop. “Thank you,” she says to Obi-Wan and then to Vokara. She tosses the wrapper in the trash and then sticks the sweet in her mouth as she leaves with her guardian.

“You did well,” Vokara tells Obi-Wan.

“So we don’t always use the Force to help?” Obi-Wan asks.

“When we can use medicine to help, we use medicine. That means we only have to use the Force when absolutely necessary. It’s tiring to use the Force and there aren’t very many Jedi trained to do it, so we want to spare them for emergencies.”

Obi-Wan contemplates this as he follows Vokara to the fresher to wash their hands before their next patient is shown in. “Does that mean I’m going to learn how to do surgeries?”

“If that’s where your focus takes you,” Vokara answers. “There is too much for any one being to be able to do everything, so we take specialties. Some have a specialty in Force healing, others in surgery or infectious diseases. But even within those specialties, there are specialties.”

“There’s so much,” Obi-Wan says.

He’s looking overwhelmed so Vokara herds him toward the hand dryer. “And you have an entire lifetime to learn it.”

“But what if someone needs help before I’ve learned how to help them?”

Vokara crouches down so they’re eye-to-eye, because this will be the most important lesson she has taught him so far. “That’s why we’re a team. If you aren’t confident in an area of healing, you reach out to one of your fellow healers. None of us can save the galaxy on our own.”

“Okay.” Obi-Wan nods as he processes this. “What should I start studying, then? What area are we weakest?”

“You’re still twelve,” Vokara reminds him. “Right now, you’re gaining a broad overview of everything. You won’t begin to specialize until sixteen. When your counterparts will become senior padawans and begin leaving the Temple more often, you’ll start your specialization. And don’t try to jump ahead. Keep an open mind. The Force will guide you when it’s time.”

Obi-Wan frowns, dissatisfied with the answer, but he doesn’t argue.

“Get me a sterile room!” Vokara shouts. Her voice cuts through the Halls and immediately there is a wave of motion. Healers and apprentices scatter to attend to their own patients or prep a room for Vokara’s.

When Vokara received a comm telling her to meet an injured Jedi at the hangar, she didn’t expect this. She will have to remind Qui-Gon Jinn that while the Council may find his scattered reports amusing, she does not.

The Jedi Master in question is practically on Vokara’s heels as she uses the Force to hold Master Tahl still and carry her into a private room. When Vokara lowers Master Tahl onto the med-bed, Qui-Gon hovers, his anxiety and worry pouring off him in waves.

“Out,” Vokara says. On the bed, her patient trembles as her body fights against the hold the Force has on her. Vokara snaps her fingers and holds her hand out. Obi-Wan places her scanner on her palm. Vokara shifts to start her scan and knocks into a body that is not supposed to be in her way.

“Out,” Vokara repeats. She doesn’t take her gaze off her patient, because she can’t afford to. But if she has to repeat herself a third time…

“She needs me,” Qui-Gon says. His grief and his guilt pour off of him. It’s enough to give Vokara a headache. If she feels as if she’s swallowing Qui-Gon’s emotions, then Tahl must have it even worse.

“Qui-Gon, come with me.”

Vokara recognizes Mace’s voice so she stops sparing any of her attention to that mess. Instead, she returns her full focus to Tahl. She doesn’t have to ask before she feels Obi-Wan’s presence in her mind. He’s learned how to make himself quiet, almost invisible while he observes.

Often, he’ll ask questions and they’ll discuss Vokara’s patients, but today he is silent. Vokara does a scan with her medical scanner while a droid does a second. The readouts aren’t positive. It’s a riot of symptoms, too many for the scanner to process. Which means this will require a more hands-on approach.

Vokara takes a deep breath and then closes her eyes so she can look with the Force. Tahl’s aura is stained. Red like blood, green-yellow like the edge of a bruise, and then the black tendrils which spread in every direction.

Poison.

The black has deep roots, and it feeds off the other colors. She needs to address those first. Tahl’s aura should be light blue, almost white like the surface of a lake on a clear day. Vokara finds Tahl’s lungs first and starts purging her aura of the poison.

It’s a slow, draining fight, but it’s the one Vokara has spent her life training for. She clears Tahl’s lungs and then her heart. She moves to Tahl’s throat next. Bit by bit the red is drained away and the green-yellow is pushed back.

Vokara exists in two worlds, the physical and the metaphysical. In the physical world, her body sways, exhausted. Even though her eyes are closed, she can see spots. A headache builds. She should take a break, rest, and resume once she’s recharged.

A fresh look at Tahl’s aura shows the black spreading more now that it has the space. Tahl will die if Vokara can’t stop this.

And if Vokara pushes herself until she collapses?

Here. Obi-Wan offers a well of power for Vokara to draw from. Obi-Wan has made tremendous progress since becoming her padawan, but he can’t heal Tahl. What he can do, however, is offer his own reserves for Vokara to use.

Thank you. Vokara taps into Obi-Wan’s power. It’s crisp and refreshing, like a dip in the pool. It’s like drinking a shot of espresso. The world is sharper, she feels brighter. She takes a steadying breath and fights again for Tahl’s recovery.

#

It takes three days of Vokara and Obi-Wan working in tandem to burn the poison from Tahl’s system. Vokara leaves the rest of Tahl’s injuries to her very capable staff and then falls into bed with her padawan at her side.

They sleep for almost an entire day and then there’s the long, blurred process of becoming sentient again. Vokara starts with a shower and then clean, simple clothes and then food. She has enough wherewithal to set her padawan through the same process.

She is exhausted, an uncomfortable weight in her limbs and dark circles under her eyes, but she’ll recover.

Even better, Tahl will as well.

Obi-Wan watches Healer Drovan attend to Tahl with the help of two droids. Vokara sips her caf, her third cup already, and braces herself for the inevitable questions. Obi-Wan will have a dozen at least, and he deserves answers to them. Force healing is an art and one they haven’t practiced often together.

“She came from Melida/Daan,” Obi-Wan says.

It isn’t the opening Vokara expects.

“Mission reports are available in the Archives,” Obi-Wan tells Vokara.

Vokara makes a note to have a conversation with Jocasta about enabling her padawan. If Jocasta wanted Obi-Wan as a future archivist, Jocasta could have made an offer.

“I was curious.” Obi-Wan’s voice dips as if he senses the change in Vokara’s mood. And then he straightens his shoulders as if preparing for an argument. “There’s a war on Melida/Daan. Master Tahl was captured and hurt. We were barely able to help her with all the resources the Temple has.”

“But we did help her,” Vokara says.

“Melida/Daan doesn’t have a Jedi Temple,” Obi-Wan says. “Where will their injured go? Who will help them?”

Oh. Vokara knows Jedi are encouraged to take padawans to keep them humble. Yes, it is her role to teach her padawan, but it is her duty to learn from her padawan in turn.

“You’re correct,” Vokara says. “Melida/Daan needs help.”

“And we can help them?”

“We can. I’m going to speak with the Council. I want you to go to the Archives and ask Archivist Nu for assistance with a Republic Relief Request.”

Obi-Wan bobs his head and then trots off to carry out his mission. Vokara finishes her caf and then pours herself a fresh cup. She’ll need it for this upcoming fight with the Council.

#

Vokara, Obi-Wan, Master Tivok, his padawan Cuit and Knight Tristane are the Jedi assigned to the Melida/Daan case. Vokara and Obi-Wan will work with the Republic Relief team to supply and tend to the war refugees while the other Jedi are tasked with bringing the war to its end.

Obi-Wan spends the flight to Melida/Daan sleeping or learning everything he can from the Republic Relief workers. Vokara leaves him to it. She sleeps as much as she can to bolster her energy and her reserves before they hit the ground.

Due to Tahl’s report, they avoid the major city and spaceport. Knowing they would likely not have a place to land, they took a ship which could handle being parked outside a hangar. They land in an open space once they determine it isn’t a field or a farm or any kind of necessary land.

The copilot reported signs of a settlement about ten klicks away. There is a brief discussion of who would go with what supplies. It’s eventually decided that Knight Tristane will act as escort for Vokara and Obi-Wan and a small number of the relief workers. They’ll do an initial check and, if the settlement is safe, the rest of them will join and begin their work.

They’re two kliks out when a warning shot stops them where they are.

“Turn around!” a voice calls out.

“We have food,” Vokara tells them. “And medical supplies.”

“Elders aren’t welcome here.”

Before Vokara can respond, Obi-Wan steps forward. Despite almost a year in her care, Obi-Wan is on the small size for one his age and species, as if he believes his body takes up more space than it should. His padawan braid is still barely more than a stub, and while his robes are simple and clean, they don’t give him any kind of imitation factor.

Obi-Wan steps forward, his hands raised in a gesture of peace, and all Vokara can think is how young he looks. This child she chose, the one she swore to protect. He’s small, but he’s an easy target for anyone with good aim. Her instincts scream at her to reach for him and pull him back, but the Force cautions her against it.

“I’m not an Elder,” Obi-Wan says.

There’s a long silence.

“You’re allowed,” the voice finally says. “Only you. Bring your offering.”

“And you won’t harm my companions?” Obi-Wan asks. “We’re here to help. I won’t see more bodies added to the count.”

“They can return to where they came from,” the voice says. “If they don’t attack us, we won’t attack them.”

“Agreed,” Obi-Wan says.

All Vokara can do now is trust.

#

Vokara sees through Obi-Wan’s eyes. Their bond is strong, stronger than most masters and padawans, but healers always have a strong connection. They are inside each other’s minds daily for training, and it builds a bridge which is easily crossed.

She almost wishes the distance was enough to lessen their bond. Even after all her years as a healer in the field and a healer at the Temple, it hurts to see this community of children. They’re injured, sick, and half-starved. None of them have the strength to fight an enemy beyond their walls let alone the battle inside their bodies.

Vokara watches as Obi-Wan runs himself ragged trying to help as many as he can. But even with the medical supplies he brought and the support of the Force, he is only one person. His tears are hers when the first child passes into the Force. His grief is hers and it feels as if it’s ripping her apart. His screams are hers and her throat is sore for an entire day.

“I thought you said you could help!” The voice, Vokara now knows it belongs to a teenager named Mawat, is angry. The boy grabs Obi-Wan by the shoulders and shakes him. “What good are you? They’re still dying!”

“Of course, they are!” Obi-Wan is tired, not only physically but his soul as well. Vokara feels more of his energy drained with every moment, but there isn’t anything she can do, stuck here on the transport while they wait to be allowed to help.

But beneath the exhaustion is anger, and as Obi-Wan taps into it he finds a new rush of energy. He shoves Mawat away from him. “I have medicine, but I’m only one person. I can only help those I can help. And I have. The ones who are dying? Their deaths are on you, because there are those who can help, and you refuse to let them.”

“They’re Elders!”

“No,” Obi-Wan says and his voice is hardened by anger but also by determination. “The Melida, the Daan, they are Elders. You don’t trust them, and you have no reason to. But the people who came with me, they’re my people. They can be trusted. They can help. You just have to let them in.” Obi-Wan’s voice drops to a near-whisper. “There’s more food. There’s more supplies. Please, Mawat. Let me contact them. Let them help.”

Obi-Wan holds his breath and so Vokara holds her as well.

“Fine,” Mawat says. “Tell them to come.”

#

Even with the relief workers and five Jedi, they can’t save everyone. Vokara knows Obi-Wan commits each name to memory. She knows he goes with Cerasi and Nield, the leaders of the war effort, to place the bodies at the memorials. She wonders if she should stop him from doing it or if it’s a necessary closure.

It has been a long time since Vokara had a padawan. She forgot how difficult it is. She’s raised two, and Obi-Wan is her third. But she doesn’t have all the answers. And she worries over the consequences of her choices.

#

“We can’t save everyone,” Obi-Wan tells her, after one of his trips to the monuments. “But we can honor them.”

Vokara indulges in a rare show of sentimentality, and she leans down until she can press a kiss to Obi-Wan’s forehead.

#

There are negotiations and battles, but those happen in the background. Vokara’s life, Obi-Wan’s life, isn’t about fighting for the planet. They’re about fighting for a single life, one at a time.

Obi-Wan learns field medicine and Force healing. He learns when to swear and when to pray and when to walk to the edge of the encampment and scream. He learns how incredible his abilities are and he learns their limitations.

If Vokara had known they were entering a warzone with child soldiers, she isn’t sure she would have let Obi-Wan accompany her.

#

When the war finally ends, there are cheers and celebrations, but Vokara doesn’t indulge, because the war is over, but her work isn’t. Obi-Wan remains at her side, and they heal those they can, and ease the pain of those who are returned to the Force.

Before they leave the planet, Vokara goes to one of the monuments with Obi-Wan and the new leaders of Melidaan, Cerasi and Nield. The two were children of leaders of the opposing factions. They found each other on the street one day and decided they would break the cycle of violence and revenge. They would not follow in the paths of their parents and their families and their faction. They would do something new.

“No one remembers how the war began,” Cerasi says as she stares at the slab of stone with the names of everyone lost. There are names missing from the stone and still it’s too long. “But everyone will know how it ended.”

She joins Nield and leans into his side as they stare at the stone. Vokara stands behind Obi-Wan and rests her hand on his shoulder. His emotions are jumbled, as she’d expect them to be. This list of names, it is a recording of lives lost. Many of them before Vokara and Obi-Wan arrived but there are ones lost while they were here.

Guilt and shame are strong amongst Obi-Wan’s feelings, as if this monument is a condemnation. Vokara squeezes his shoulder. We can only do what we can do, padawan.

I know, Obi-Wan says and she can feel the truth in his words. It doesn’t lessen the ache in his chest. They did everything they could, and it wasn’t enough. It’s a mindset many healers begin with. Those who can’t shake it burn out or drop out.

Vokara has learned to live with the knowledge that there will always be those she can’t help. She will do what she can, and she will celebrate those lives saved. She will, quietly, mourn those she couldn’t save, and then she will move on. No monuments, no litanies. If she remembered, she wouldn’t rise from her bed in the mornings.

We all learn our own ways of coping, Vokara tells Obi-Wan. She will share with him what she does. Maybe, it will help him. Maybe, it won’t.

“I’m ready to go home,” Obi-Wan says.

“So am I,” Vokara says. And then, tucked safely behind her shields, where Obi-Wan won’t hear, she thinks that she is quite ready to stay home. There will be plenty of opportunity for Obi-Wan to see war and death and suffering in his life.

If she has her way, and she nearly always does, they won’t leave the Temple again until he’s a senior padawan.

Mace Windu knows the Jedi Order isn’t infallible. In some ways, he knows this more than anyone else. Seeing shatterpoints means he knows people and choices can have far reaching impacts on the galaxy, no matter how average a person appears or how simple a choice is.

Knowing there are flaws within the Order doesn’t mean he knows the best way to address them. Just as knowing a moment is significant doesn’t mean he knows how or why or which choice should be made.

The Force has always been chaotic around Obi-Wan Kenobi, but the Force is chaotic around most beings. There are thousands of futures tied into every being. If Mace stops for a croissant before going to the Senate, will he delay his trip and miss a speeder accident? If he stops for a croissant, will he delay his trip and get into a speeder accident?

The possibilities are endless and impossible to quantify. He cannot chase every way the galaxy might shift, or he will go mad. He has to listen when the Force is particularly insistent and do the best he can.

He doesn’t know what the future of galaxy would have been if Obi-Wan Kenobi was sent to the AgriCorps. He isn’t even certain what the future of the galaxy will be now that Obi-Wan is still with the Temple. He has to trust that it’s better. And, because the future is not fixed, because it is always in motion, he must do what he can to continue to improve the galaxy’s future.

Today, Mace takes a much smaller view.

Obi-Wan Kenobi finishes his warm-up. He was aware of Mace’s presence, because he looked over when Mace first entered, but now he gives Mace his full attention. “Is there something I can assist you with, Councilor?”

Polite and composed, Obi-Wan Kenobi could have easily been a diplomat. Endless possibilities, Mace reminds himself, and then he focuses on the present. “I’ve seen you in the salles and with the battle master, Padawan Kenobi. Your Soresu is impressive.”

It’s more than impressive, and Mace can see how it will only become better as Obi-Wan ages and continues to practice. Soresu is known at the defensive form. There are those who scoff at it, because it isn’t a direct attack, but there is a strength many overlook in the form. Soresu doesn’t wear down an opponent with flashy or powerful moves. It wears them down by refusing to yield.

A master of Soresu is a master of themselves. They are a fixed point that weathers an unrelenting storm. And once the storm wears itself out, the master remains.

Obi-Wan hasn’t achieved mastery of the form, but the glimpses of it are there. Already, he can stand against any padawan or senior padawan at the Temple and hold his own. He waits and waits and waits and then, once they’re tired, he ends the spar.

He doesn’t have the endurance yet to defeat many knights or any of the masters, but he’s still quite young. Mace has watched Obi-Wan’s progress at Vokara’s request and now, again at her request, he has an offer to make.

“Thank you,” Obi-Wan says. Again, the polite smile, even a bow to acknowledge Mace’s words, but he doesn’t believe it. He holds himself back as if waiting for the follow-up.

Vokara was right. The Order has harmed this child. Mace only hopes they can also help heal him.

“Healer Che has asked me to supplement your Soresu training with Shien.”

“Form Five?” Obi-Wan asks.

“Shien is known for its transitions, from defense to offense and back again. As a healer, your dedication to defense is understandable, but there will be circumstances where being able to employ a quick, pointed attack will be useful.”

“If I need to reach a patient,” Obi-Wan says. “Or if our healing station is attacked. We begin with katas?”

“We begin with a demonstration,” Mace says. He hangs his robes on a hook and then ignites his saber. The purple blade sets him apart from most Jedi. There are some who judge him for it and some who treat him as a danger and others who see him as special or Force-blessed. He always wants to laugh and tell them it’s a damn crystal color. It isn’t a sign or a warning. It just is.

He doesn’t show off, but he does show, moving from Soresu to Shien and back. He can feel Obi-Wan’s gaze on him, curious and attentive, and when Mace finishes, Obi-Wan nods, seemingly to himself.

“I understand,” Obi-Wan says. “Will you show me the first kata?”

#

Obi-Wan doesn’t complain when Mace has him do basic katas over and over again. He doesn’t protest when Mace has Obi-Wan teach in addition to learn. He accepts each decision Mace makes and then applies himself to the task.

“He’s making good progress,” Mace tells Vokara during what has become a standing weekly meeting between the two of them. They will sometimes venture out of the Temple to stop at a cantina or a café, but they always end in one of their quarters to speak freely while they enjoy their procured victuals.

“Of course, he is.” Vokara scoffs as if she isn’t sure why Mace feels the need to tell her something she already knows. “Have you told Obi-Wan?”

“As often as I feel I can,” Mace answers. He hums quietly and stirs his drink to keep the flavor from sinking to the bottom. “He is suspicious of praise. At times, he believes it’s a lie. At others, he believes it’s a set-up.”

“We do our initiates a disservice with the way we handle the Corps,” Vokara says. “We raise them to believe they’ll be knights or failures.”

“You want me to push for a change within the Order.”

“Astute,” Vokara says.

The Jedi Order adheres to tradition, and Mace knows there are benefits to such a long, rich history. But one of those benefits is to learn from it. They are becoming stagnant. And if they do not continue to grow, they will fall behind or become obsolete.

“I suppose you have some suggestions?” Mace asks.

“Of course.” Vokara gives Mace an arch look. “I suppose you want me to do all the work for you?”

Mace laughs and then takes a sip of his drink. “I appreciate any assistance you wish to give.”

#

Every month the Temple hosts a friendly competition for anyone who wishes to participate. It’s a lightsaber tournament, and it pits knights against senior padawans and senior padawans against masters.

It’s an opportunity to socialize and make a few friendly wagers.

Mace doesn’t participate in this one, but he joins some of the other Jedi in one of the observation rooms. Vokara is here, a drink already in hand, and she shakes her head at whatever Tholme has just told her.

“I’m off-duty. I’m here as a spectator, not a healer.” Vokara smiles when she spots Mace and waves him over.

He makes his way through his colleagues, nodding in greeting to some, verbally greeting others. He reaches Vokara and Tholme. “How do the brackets look today?”

“You haven’t already reviewed them?” Tholme asks. “I suppose you aren’t betting, then.”

“Mace isn’t betting?” Jocasta Nu joins them with a drink in each hand. She keeps the fizzing green one for herself and hands Mace the purple one with a little smile crinkling her eyes. “No faith in Obi-Wan?”

“I have plenty of faith in Obi-Wan,” Mace says. Even though Obi-Wan is in the salles itself, out of earshot of the gossips above, he worries the boy might somehow overhear. “Who are his opponents?”

“His only opponent is Padawan Muln,” Jocasta says. “The rest are potential opponents.”

Mace doesn’t roll his eyes, only because he’s too well-trained. He does sip his drink. It’s sweet, fruity, with a bit of a kick which means someone’s been distilling their own liquor in the Archives again. He gives Jocasta an arch look.

“Oh, lighten up, Mace,” she says.

“Is Padawan Vos participating?” Vokara asks Tholme, no doubt trying to head off Mace and Jocasta’s bickering before they can get going. Mace is almost certain Jocasta Nu spends her time in the Archives coming up with ways to annoy him during Council meetings.

“He is. He has a few new moves he wants to try.”

“Should we be concerned?” Mace asks. Things catch on fire at an alarming rate when Quinlan Vos decides to be creative. Not to mention, Mace is all but convinced Vos is behind the protocol droids gaining a language upgrade which taught them how to curse.

“No need for concern,” Tholme says. “Quinlan’s calmed down these past few years.”

Mace isn’t the only one to give Tholme an incredulous look.

“Padawan Vos has an apprentice healer for a friend,” Vokara says. “He causes trouble and Obi-Wan helps him clean it up. It’s good training so I haven’t discouraged it. My guess, by the time Obi-Wan is ready to be knighted, quarter credit will go to Vos.”

“That’s a bit generous, don’t you think?” Thomle asks.

On the salles floor, Padawan Vos gives a Devaronian war cry and then launches into an aggressive attack against his first opponent. Two minutes into the fight, Knight Solar has tossed Padawan Vos’s lightsaber aside and Padawan Vos has resorted to leaping on Knight Solar’s back to tackle him to the ground.

Tholme sighs but lurking beneath the exasperation is a bit of pride.

#

The observation room has windows into each of the four salles being used for the tournament. Mace still hasn’t finished his first drink by the time Obi-Wan wins his first bout. It was a standard fight, padawan against padawan, and the two are friends so while it was competitive, there was no edge to it.

“Was that Shien I saw Padawan Kenobi using?” Tholme asks. “You’ve taught him well.”

“I’ve taught him,” Mace corrects. “He learned well.”

“Maybe I’ll place a wager on him. Oh.” Tholme’s voice dips, disappointed. “Unlucky second draw.”

Mace looks at the updated brackets and sees what Tholme must have seen. Obi-Wan’s next opponent is Yan Dooku. The older master isn’t in the Temple often these days. He’s kept his distance since Galidraan. Personally, Mace thinks Yoda should spend more time bringing his lineage together and less time adding to it, but he keeps those thoughts to himself.

Still, it’s good to see Yan in the Temple.

There are several murmurs of sympathy directed at Vokara as her padawan prepares to face off against a venerated Jedi master and skilled duelist. For his part, Obi-Wan shows no outward signs of distress. He wipes the sweat from his forehead, takes another drink from his water bottle, and then picks his saber up off the bench he left it on.

Mace isn’t surprised when Obi-Wan falls into a Soresu stance after bowing to Yan. While Obi-Wan’s Shien has improved greatly, it’s no match for Yan’s Makashi. Mace isn’t sure Soresu will fare much better, but it’s Obi-Wan’s first form and the one he’s most comfortable in.

Vokara hums softly as she stands next to Mace. “This will be good for him.”

Mace, busy watching, doesn’t ask her which him she refers to.

#

Mace and Vokara are two of the only Jedi to have watched Obi-Wan and Yan’s bout for its entirety. Given that they’re entering their second hour, it isn’t too shocking.

The duel began the way Mace expected. Obi-Wan was steady in his defense, and Yan probed his guard for weaknesses, but didn’t bring a full-on attack. It’s a sign of respect from masters to padawans to not end the fight in the first few minutes. But what began as a training exercise has become something else entirely.

Yan has attacked with speed, he has attacked with grace, and he has attacked with frustration. Obi-Wan has remained steady through it all. He matches Yan’s speed, his skill, his power with an infallible defense.

Obi-Wan parries, he guards, he meets each attack with the exact amount of energy it requires and no more. He stands his ground when he needs to, and he cedes it when it’s advantageous.

While both padawan and master have sweated through their clothes, Obi-Wan’s expression is far more serene than Yan’s. The boy seems relaxed as he holds his own against one of the Order’s most talented duelists.

“Ah, to be young again.” Master Vito joins Mace and Vokara. He’s an elderly Bothan and last year he was taken off the active mission roster. He still shares his knowledge through teaching courses and spending time in the creche.

“It isn’t youth,” Vokara says. “Obi-Wan doesn’t have raw power, but he has this.” She inclines her head as if they aren’t also watching Obi-Wan as he twists away from Yan’s latest attack. Obi-Wan’s saber crackles against Yan’s as he fends off a strike.

When the two part, it’s Yan who looks frustrated.

#

It takes four hours for the duel to end. The rest of the bouts have finished, and a winner has been named despite the second-round fight still taking place.

It’s Yan who wins the fight, after he slips through Obi-Wan’s guard in a rare moment of weakness.

“You should be proud,” Mace tells Vokara, because Obi-Wan did far better than Mace would have expected for his age and experience.

Vokara doesn’t smile or even try to hide a pleased reaction. She looks troubled as Obi-Wan is swarmed by his friends. Padawan Vos claps him hard enough on the back to knock him over and Padawan Muln catches him before he falls. Padawan Eerin fusses and holds out both a water bottle and a strip of jerky.

“They say the Force provides,” Vokara says.

It’s only the two of them on this side of the observation room. They’re some of the few Jedi remaining now that the main event and side event are over.

“Some say the Force doesn’t ask for more than we can give,” Vokara continues.

Mace waits, patient for the conclusion she’s leading them both to.

“What does the galaxy hold that my padawan needs that kind of endurance?”

Mace looks down at Obi-Wan. The boy laughs as he dumps half his water over his head to cool off. His face is flushed, and he now drips with both water and sweat. He’s tired but he isn’t exhausted.

Around him, the Force swells and recedes. There are a thousand futures all vying for their opportunity.

“You should be proud,” Mace repeats.

Obi-Wan ducks around a corner and curses under his breath as the blaster bolt meant for him hits the building instead. He doesn’t have the opportunity to catch his breath, because the shooter isn’t content with a close call.

He sprints down the road and then slips into a shop.

The shopkeeper urges him toward a trap door. Obi-Wan hesitates long enough for the Force to warn him if needed and, when it’s quiet, he drops into the cellar. By the time his pursuer is in the shop, their boots heavy on the wooden floor, the trap door is closed, and the rug has been rolled over it.

Obi-Wan sits in the dark and breathes slowly. He twists his padawan braid around his finger, a nervous habit he hasn’t quite shaken. The bead at the end helps settle him. It’s his Senior Padawan bead. Healer Che gave it to him only a few months ago.

And now he’s here, on his first mission since.

When the trap door opens again, it’s the shopkeeper who waves at him.

Obi-Wan climbs up the ladder. “Vor entye,” Obi-Wan says, thanking the shopkeeper.

They smile, probably at his accent which isn’t as smooth as it could be. “What did you do to have them after you?”

Them, being members of Death Watch or Kyr’tsad as they’re called in Mando’a. Obi-Wan and Garen were both sent to Mandalore at the same time. They were even both sent to Keldabe. But where Garen and his master were sent to protect Duchess Satine Kryze, Obi-Wan’s been tasked with the civilians who are under threat from the terrorist sect.

Those who aren’t chasing Garen and Satine across the Mandalore system are trying to rule Keldabe with fear. They don’t appreciate Obi-Wan’s efforts to keep hope and resistance alive.

“I’m a healer,” Obi-Wan says. “With the attacks, I’m running low on supplies, and they have plenty lying around.” Speaking of, he opens his satchel. “Is there anything you or your family need?”

“Aliit,” the shopkeeper says.

“Aliit?” Obi-Wan repeats. He scans his satchel. It’s basic foodstuffs and medical supplies. His Mando’a isn’t great. The shopkeeper could be asking for anything.

“Family,” the shopkeeper says. “Clan. Aliit.”

“Ah. Do you have any children?”

“Ade,” the shopkeepers says.

“Ade.” Obi-Wan commits the word to memory. “Do you have any?”

The shopkeeper smiles. “Three.” Their smile dims. “The curfew is hard on them.”

Obi-Wan takes three sweets from his satchel. Kyr’tsad didn’t have any lollipops that he saw, but this is close enough. He places the candy on the table. “If you need my services, there are those in Keldabe who know how to signal me.”

“Baar’ur,” the shopkeeper says. Medic.

Obi-Wan smiles. He knows that one.

#

Obi-Wan aims his blaster and returns fire. He hears a curse as he hits his target. He shoots again, twice in quick succession. He hits his target but there are no more curses. He swallows back his reservations and his guilt and takes aim again.

Behind him, he hears the shouts and movement of their covert as they scramble to take as many supplies as they can. He doesn’t know if it was poor luck or betrayal which led to Kyr’tsad to their hideout, but it isn’t hidden or safe anymore.

The wounded have already been moved. Now, it’s time for the supplies. As one of the uninjured, Obi-Wan helps hold Kyr’tsad off as the others clear the area.

Next to him, Jingko lobs a grenade. It lands and smoke pours out. A second grenade lands. There’s a blinding flash, and Jingko scolds Obi-Wan for looking, even as he grabs Obi-Wan’s sleeve and hauls him away from his perch.

Blaster fire follows them deeper into the building. Obi-Wan swears as a bolt glances off his shoulder. It isn’t a direct hit, but it burns. He stumbles and then shakes off Jingko’s hand.

He follows Jingko down lower. Keldabe has plenty of flat rooftops, but Obi-Wan learned early on that going up is never the first choice. The enemy has jetpacks. Street level with tight corners and tight quarters is good. Below ground is even better.

When Kyr’tsad set off their attacks in the capital city, they expected to kill or capture the Kryze family. Both Satine and her sister made it out. With part of their forces sent to track them down, the rest of Kyr’tsad stayed to take the city and claim leadership for themselves.

What began as an aid mission has turned into something more. Obi-Wan is part of the underground resistance. If Kyr’tsad thought Keldabe would crumble under a bit of pressure, they don’t deserve to rule Mandalore. How can someone rule people they don’t understand?

Obi-Wan had been briefed on the New Mandalorians and the Kyr’tsad before coming here. He didn’t realize until he fell in with the resistance that in order to have New Mandalorians, there must have been Old Mandalorians.

They call themselves the Haat Mando’ade. They don’t embrace the violence or terror of Kyr’tsad, but they don’t adhere to the New Mandalorian peaceful philosophy. They believe in fighting, not to claim or conquer but to protect what’s theirs.

Obi-Wan fits in with them better than he thought he would.

He and Jingko shake their tail before they finally take the path to the new base. It’s in the basement of a building which has seen better days. Its construction is half the original wood and half modern durasteel.

The lights are kept low, enough to see but not enough to attract attention.

“Baar’ur?” someone calls when he’s spotted. “We need you.”

Obi-Wan hasn’t gone by his name since he fell in with the resistance. Names are dangerous. Baar’ur is a title, but it’s also what he is, and he answers to it.

“See to yourself first,” Jingko says. He grabs Obi-Wan’s shoulder before Obi-Wan is out of reach. Jingko’s fingers dig into the blaster burn, and Obi-Wan hisses. “Yourself first.”

Obi-Wan mutters something unkind in Mando’a, but he applies a bit of healing salve to the burn.

“You need armor,” Jingko says as Obi-Wan crouches down next to Inara, a youngling who lost her parents in the initial attack. Her physical injuries have healed, but she needs help settling every time they have to move their base.

“It protects you so you can protect us,” Inara says.

Obi-Wan glares at Jingko in lieu of the cutting remark he was going to make. Obi-Wan turns back to Inara and offers her a soft smile. “We can discuss it.”

#

Obi-Wan compromises, because even if he isn’t on the diplomat track at the Temple, he’s taken enough lessons to know how to politely concede ground. He doesn’t wear a full set of armor, because he needs mobility more than he needs the protection, but he does accumulate a few pieces. Vambraces, a cuirass, shoulder bells, and thigh plates. He’s certain they would give him more if he would agree.

No, not give.

He earned his armor.

And this is where Obi-Wan’s true reluctance comes in. He knows enough about Mandalorian culture now to know what their armor means to them. Their armor resonates with their soul like a Jedi’s kyber crystal resonates with a Jedi’s soul.

He isn’t Mandalorian. To wear beskar means something to them that it doesn’t mean to him. It can’t mean to him. He is Senior Padawan Obi-Wan Kenobi of the Jedi Order. But he traces his fingers over the sleek metal, and he feels it hum back at him. There is something here that speaks to him. That tempts him. Is this supposed to be a test? It’s too early for his Trials, he was only just named a senior padawan, but he can’t help but wonder.

#

Obi-Wan is grateful for his armor when a building collapses and shrapnel flies in every direction. A chunk of duracrete slams into his chest and knocks him on his ass. His chest aches, but he can pull in a full breath.

He curses as blaster fire follows the collapse. He scoops a child up off the ground and runs. Blaster bolts hit his back, but they’re stopped by his backplate. Each hit is as solid as a punch, but he doesn’t buckle. He uses the Force to direct the bolts away from his unprotected areas. The shots fizzle out on the ground around him or they beat on his armor.

When he makes it to the safehouse, there’s a standoff between a fully armored Mandalorian and the others. Behind the Mandalorian are adults in need of medical attention and care. They are bruised and cut up and some of them cradle their limbs as if part of the building had fallen on them.

“Elissa!” One of the adults holds their arms out and the child Obi-Wan brought wiggles out of Obi-Wan’s hold and rushes to the adult.

Obi-Wan grabs his satchel, and then he scans the adults until he finds the one in need of the most immediate attention. They have a long gash on their head, and the blood has soaked into their hair.

“You are here now, and there is help,” Obi-Wan tells them.

As he cleans the wound, Jingko and the armored Mandalorian finally speak.

“How can we trust you?” Jingko asks. “You were with Kyr’tsad.”

“Not by choice,” the Mandalorian says. Their vocorder flattens their voice. “They complained about the resistance movement, enough that I knew you were real. And when I saw you today, I took my chance to leave. I’m not Kyr’tsad. I’m not New Mandalorian either.”

“Who are you?” Jingko asks.

The Mandalorian removes their helmet. There are gasps throughout the room, but Obi-Wan doesn’t recognize the Mandalorian’s features. They have blond hair, close-cropped to fit under their helmet. Their eyes are sharp and intelligent, and they scan the room for threats as they converse.

When they smile, there’s something dangerous at the edges. “I am Arla, Clan Fett, House Mereel.”

Oh, Obi-Wan thinks as he applies a bit of salve to the headwound. It slows the bleeding enough for him to put in the stitches which will hold it together as it heals. He’s heard of both Clan Fett and House Mereel. Jaster Mereel was the Mand’alor, the leader until he was betrayed by one of his men and killed.

And Jango Fett was his heir, who led the True Mandalorians until Galidraan. According to the Archives, Jango Fett killed five Jedi with his bare hands before he was subdued. And then the Jedi turned him over to Kyr’tsad. It was a shameful moment in a long string of them at Galidraan. As far as Obi-Wan knows, Jango Fett is dead or as good as.

But there’s another Fett alive? Obi-Wan doesn’t have a strong grasp on Mandalorians and their familial or political ties. Does this make Arla the successor of the True Mandalorians?

“My parents gave refuge to Jaster Mereel and his super commandos,” Arla says. “Kyr’tsad followed. They killed my parents and burned our farm. Jaster managed to get my brother out. Kyr’tsad took me. But I’m free now, and I’m ready to see them burn.”

Obi-Wan places a bandage on the stitches he did and then moves to his next patient.

“Welcome,” Jingko says and the room seems to breathe easier.

#

“You are useful,” Arla says. She sits next to Obi-Wan, but he doesn’t miss the way her body is coiled, ready to spring into action, or that she has her hand resting on her blaster.

“I do my best,” Obi-Wan says. He stands beside one of the med-beds. Its occupant has a cracked rib and has been ordered to remain on strict bedrest. Whenever Obi-Wan has the time, and energy, to spare, he speeds the healing with the Force.

Today, he doesn’t have the energy, but he sits at his patient’s side and holds their hand. He has three weapons in reach, not counting his own body or the Force. Arla still puts him on edge. She looks at him as if she’s doing a threat analysis, and he isn’t sure how much time he’ll have to react if she decides he is one.

He’s heard bits and pieces of her past. How she started with Kyr’tsad as a hostage, turned into a prisoner, and then into a member on probation. She hasn’t had an easy or gentle life. He wonders how much she knows about her brother’s fate. The way her gaze narrows on his padawan braid suggests she knows enough.

The Jedi acted rashly on Galidraan and no amount of apologies or reparations will be able to undo what was done. Arla’s armor is red to honor Jaster and gold to promise vengeance. For him? For her brother? For the True Mandalorians?

“They accept you.” Arla’s gaze drops to his vambraces.

Obi-Wan has grown used to wearing the armor. It doesn’t feel odd anymore. He’s worn it often enough and trained enough in it that he’s comfortable fighting in it. “You don’t,” he says and it isn’t an accusation, simply a statement of fact.

“It’s beskar,” she says. “It’s earned, not given. They say you earned it. That should be enough.”

Obi-Wan waits, patiently, for her to sort through her thoughts.

She studies his braid again. “That is too obvious.” She produces a thin metal wire from one of her many pockets and holds it out. “Use this to hide it. Or cut it.” She shrugs as if she doesn’t care which he chooses.

“Are you going to the strategy meeting?” Obi-Wan asks. He doesn’t attend because he’s an outsider, because he’s a baar’ur, not a fighter. But it’s obvious Arla is a rallying figure. Her connections, her survival, they’re both admired and respected. At her curt nod, Obi-Wan says, “We could use more medical supplies.”

“We could use a base,” she says and then pushes off her chair and leaves.

#

This isn’t the first time Obi-Wan has done his own braid. He prefers it when Healer Che does it, but it isn’t an option. He braids his strands of hair around the wire; master, padawan, the Force, and beskar all woven together in harmony. When he finishes, he uses the wire to twist his braid up so it’s hidden by the rest of his hair.

#

With Arla leading them, the resistance becomes more than a team doing their best to react to Kyr’tsad’s attacks. They launch their own in response. Within months, Keldabe is under control of the True Mandalorians, and they are operating out of Keldabe’s Great Hall.

Obi-Wan has an entire medbay to call his own. He has supplies with the ability to requisition more. He has instruments and droids, and it isn’t as fully equipped as the Halls of Healing, but it’s enough for the people of this city.

The true sign of Keldabe’s prosperity, of course, is the return of market days. Chortav Meshurkaane is filled again, and people walk the streets freely and without fear. Obi-Wan spends more than one afternoon wandering through the market.

The Great Hall is once again a training center as Arla and the other True Mandalorians train anyone who wants to learn how to fight. As their numbers grow, they secure the surrounding farms along the Kelita River. And then the nearby towns and then other cities as well.

By the time communications have been restored, the True Mandalorians have a stronghold in this part of the planet.

Which is, of course, when they learn that Duchess Satine survived the attempts on her life and is now presiding from a seat of government in Sundari.

“Is this to be another civil war?” Jingko asks.

Arla scoffs. “It won’t be much of one. The New Mandalorians have no fight.”

“But they have the Senate,” Obi-Wan says. He doesn’t normally join the conversation when the advisors gather together, but today he has something to contribute. “Satine Kryze was guarded and protected by the Jedi at the order of the Senate, because the Senate recognizes her as the ruler of Mandalore. If this becomes a war, you won’t be fighting the New Mandalorians. You’ll be fighting the Republic.”

“So we aren’t even supposed to try?” Arla demands. She looks as though she’s prepared to fight and that Obi-Wan will make a good first target. “Mandalore is our home. She came here from Kalevala with her ideas about peace. At least Kyr’tsad killed us so we could die a warrior’s death. Satine will take our souls. She’ll make dar’manda out of us all.”

“I pointed out why civil war would be a poor option,” Obi-Wan says. “But there are other options.”

“You mean politics.” Arla isn’t the only one to show disgust.

“It’s a fight on the enemy’s terrain,” Obi-Wan says. “It isn’t a warrior’s first choice, but it is your best choice. Approach it like a battle. Learn the players, learn their strategies, and their weapons. And then lay siege.”

#

Obi-Wan leaves Mandalore two years after he first landed. Mandalore isn’t united when he leaves, Arla and Satine are two powerful women who disagree with the other completely, but it isn’t ripping itself apart anymore.

He packs his armor away on his transport back to the Temple. He tried to give it to Arla before he left. The armorers could melt it down, craft something for a True Mandalorian. Arla wouldn’t accept it. She told him he had earned it and it was his until he was underserving or he met his death.

Beskar’gam doesn’t have any place in a Jedi Temple, though, so Obi-Wan tucks it beneath his robes. He’ll keep it in his room at the Temple. There may be other missions where it would be useful to have the protection.

He keeps the beskar wire in his braid. When Healer Che does his braid for the first time after Mandalore, her fingers pause, but she doesn’t say anything when she sees it. She simply incorporates it into Obi-Wan’s braid, the way he had.

Obi-Wan arrives on Naboo with a team of Jedi and a Republic Relief squad under his command. He’s twenty-five which is young in most of their minds. The beard he’s desperately trying to grow helps but it isn’t enough. The padawan braid doesn’t help either.

He knows this is his Trial. Healer Che didn’t say anything and neither did Councilor Windu or anyone else at the Temple, but Obi-Wan’s always had a bit of precognition. The scope of this mission and his role in it suggests this is his Trial. If he passes, he will become a full-fledged healer within the Order.

A rare strain of the common Nubian flu has spread through Theed and the surrounding area. Obi-Wan and his team are here to halt the spread of the virus and find a vaccine for it before it claims too many lives.

He sets up in the palace to do his research and monitor the health of the queen and her handmaidens. It takes a month, but they develop the vaccine and then figure out how to mass-produce it.

Obi-Wan trains each of the healers with him in how to create the vaccine and administer it. He assigns each Jedi two Republic relief workers and then gives them their city assignments. They’ll set up a vaccination clinic in their city and train others as they administer the vaccine so they can spread to more cities and then towns.

“Good work, you are doing,” Master Yoda says during Obi-Wan’s weekly check-in.

Obi-Wan inclines his head. “Thank you, Master Yoda.” Obi-Wan is in the city proper, staying at the local hospital even though Queen Amidala had been kind enough to offer him a place in the palace. His work is in the hospital and so he sleeps as close to his work as he’s allowed. “The Force is…troubled.”

Master Yoda’s ears flatten against his head. “Troubled times, these are.”

“Master Jinn and Knight Solar have been dispatched to Naboo,” Councilor Windu tells Obi-Wan. “The Trade Federation is creating difficulties for Naboo. The two will negotiate a peaceful resolution. It shouldn’t affect your work but stay attentive.”

“I will,” Obi-Wan promises. “Do Master Jinn and Knight Solar know I’m on planet? If there is any assistance I can give them, I will.”

“We will let them know,” Councilor Windu says. “May the Force be with you, Padawan Kenobi.”

“And also with you, Councilor.”

#

The room shakes. Obi-Wan throws his hands out to stabilize his patients and the machines they’re hooked up to. Around him, vials fall to the floor and shatter. Scalpels and hyposprays and other equipment fall off trays and tables and scatter across the floor.

There are shouts of surprise and grunts of pain, and Obi-Wan does his best to hold as much steady as he can. When everything settles, he rushes to check and make sure they didn’t lose power during whatever just happened.

“Someone find out what just happened!” Obi-Wan calls. He makes sure the oxygen tanks are still working and the kidney dialysis hasn’t stopped. There are over a dozen machines all keeping people alive in this very room, and he allows himself a moment of relief when he realizes they’re still functioning.

And then he sets about putting his patients at ease.

#

“A blockade?” Obi-Wan repeats.

The Nubian guard who brought the information nods. There’s dirt and soot streaked across his face, and a few superficial cuts that he’s already turned down treatment for. “There is a blockade on the planet, and the Trade Federation has initiated a full-scale invasion.”

“Force help us,” Obi-Wan murmurs.

#

The work camps are grueling. Obi-Wan had tucked his braid away when the invasion reached the hospital, and he hid his lightsaber. Passing himself off as Nubian spared his life, but it also landed him here.

He works a full shift every day under the close watch of their droid overseers and then he works a second shift in the slapdash medic tent. He treats what wounds he can and then does his best to battle exhaustion and fear.

Naboo is a peaceful planet, and the Nubians put up almost no resistance to the invasion force. Obi-Wan is surrounded by civilians who don’t understand why anyone wishes them harm. It doesn’t help that rumors say the queen has abandoned her planet, escaped with a Jedi guard and left Naboo to its fate.

How many check-ins has Obi-Wan missed with the Council? Surely, they’ve heard of the blockade. Is help coming? For everyone or only a private rescue for him and the other Jedi?

He doesn’t have access to enough information. All he can do is trust in the Force and keep as many people alive as he can until a rescue comes.

#

“Something is wrong,” Obi-Wan says. He looks around as a wave of Gungans storm through the droids guarding the work camp. A rescue is here, but Obi-Wan can’t shake the heavy, oppressive warning the Force sends his way.

He has a bad feeling about this.

#

The closer Obi-Wan gets to the palace, the darker the Force feels. Something is very, very wrong.

He sneaks in, his entry made easier by the chaos in the halls. He isn’t the first to break into the palace. There’s some kind of revolt happening. There are Nubian guards fighting against droids and their masters. He thinks he hears someone say Queen Amidala has returned.

Obi-Wan reaches the throne room in time to see Queen Amidala point her blaster at a Neimoidian.

A guard draws a blaster on Obi-Wan. “Who are you and how did you make it in here?”

“I am Obi-Wan Kenobi.” Obi-Wan draws his saber out of its hiding place, but he doesn’t ignite it. “I’m a Jedi, and I’m here to help.”

“We have this situation handled,” Queen Amidala says. Her voice is young, but there is steel in her words. “Your fellow Jedi went to the reactor room to face a threat there.”

The Force grows more insistent, and Obi-Wan doesn’t waste any time. He runs, guided by the Force and the thick, choking darkness it’s trying to expel.

Obi-Wan skids into the room in time to see a Zabrak wielding a red lightsaber drive the point of it through Master Jinn’s chest.

“No!” Obi-Wan shouts.

The Zabrak jerks back, and Master Jinn slumps to the ground. Obi-Wan ignites his saber and charges forward. Before he makes it more than three steps, a green blade pushes through the Zabrak’s chest. It’s the Zabrak’s turn to fall. Their saber powers down and rolls across the floor.

Behind the Zabrak stands Knight Solar in torn, singed robes. He has a wild look in his eyes as if he can’t quite believe what he just did.

“Contact the Council,” Obi-Wan says, snapping into action. This is why he’s a healer, because he doesn’t freeze in situations like this. He’s at Master Jinn’s side in an instant. The lightsaber pierced his lung but not his heart. He’s still alive, if only barely. “Tell them what’s happened. Tell them to send Healer Che and do not let anyone separate me from Master Jinn.”

“What?” Knight Solar turns to face Obi-Wan. “Why?”

“What I’m about to do will save his life or cost both of ours,” Obi-Wan says.

And then he closes his eyes and opens himself up to the Force.

#

The Force is present in all things. It does not require belief in order to exist. It simply is. It is in the cores of planets and their atmospheres. It is in naturally growing plants and artificially created minerals. It is in sentients all across the galaxy.

Master Jinn has a hole in one of his lungs. His heart isn’t directly damaged, but the strain of the fight and then the attack was too much. Obi-Wan weaves his Force presence through Master Jinn’s.

When Obi-Wan breathes, Master Jinn breathes.

When Obi-Wan’s heart beats, Master Jinn’s heart beats.

If Master Jinn dies, Obi-Wan will as well.

But there is no room for doubt in his mind. There is not even room for hope. All there is is the Force.

Obi-Wan breathes. He lives.

And Master Jinn lives with him.

#

Obi-Wan wakes up on a soft, familiar mattress. The walls around him a painted a soothing blue-gray. There is no pain pressing on him from all sides. There is no despair, no deeply rooted depression. There is…peace.

He blinks the sleep out of his eyes. He’s in his room at the Temple. He waits a moment. Nothing changes. He counts his fingers, raising each one as he goes. And then he counts down.

This isn’t a dream.

He rises and then promptly falls back onto his bed as his legs give out. He remembers the work camps on Naboo. He remembers the invasion. He remembers sneaking into the palace. He remembers the cold, creep of the dark.

He remembers Master Jinn.

Obi-Wan’s second attempt to rise is far more successful than his first. He leans against his wall until his legs agree to support him. He showers and changes into fresh clothes. He makes himself a cup of Insta-Caf because he doesn’t have the patience to brew a proper cup and then he heads for the Halls of Healing.

He doesn’t make it past the doors.

Healer Nikita plucks the caf from his hands. “You aren’t supposed to be out of bed. And you certainly aren’t supposed to be drinking caf.”

“What happened?” Obi-Wan asks. “How long has it been? Is Master Jinn alright?”

Healer Nikita allows Obi-Wan into the Halls, but she guides him to the break room. She sits him at one of the tables and then fetches him a glass of water and heats up a bowl of oatmeal. She sits across from him and keeps her answers to herself until he takes his first bite of food.

The oatmeal is warm and filling. It’s apple-cinnamon, the flavor enough to tempt his senses but not so much as to overwhelm them. He eats in greedy spoonfuls and his bowl is empty before he’s even aware of it.

“Huh,” he says.

Healer Nikita hands him a muffin next. “You tethered Master Jinn’s self to your own. You kept him steady and stable until Healer Che could arrive. She healed him enough to put him in a healing trance and then brought both of you home. You’ve been asleep since she separated you from Master Jinn.”

It would explain why Obi-Wan’s so hungry. He eats his muffin, drinks his water, and then searches for something else to eat. “He’ll live?”

“Healer Che is optimistic. What you did, you kept him alive. But he was badly injured. There’s no current prediction on how long he’ll be in his trance and even if he wakes from it, he has a long road to recovery ahead of him.”

“But he’ll live,” Obi-Wan says.

“Force willing,” Healer Nikita says.

#

Obi-Wan stands in front of the High Council and does his best not to fidget. Today is a moment of celebration, but he finds it difficult to be happy knowing Master Jinn’s status is still uncertain.

It’s been two days since Obi-Wan woke up, three days since his return to the Temple.

Healer Che clears her throat and fixes Obi-Wan with a look he’s grown used to over the years. She has been a demanding teacher, but she has never asked for more than he could give. How many times over the years has he been told he’s a credit to her teaching? He hopes she knows each of those were a compliment to her.

“I wanted to put this off,” Healer Che says. “Because after this ceremony, I can’t order you to bed, and you haven’t fully recovered.”

Obi-Wan laughs and it breaks the heavy tension in the room. “You are the Chief Healer at the Temple. You can order anyone at any time.”

“That’s true.” Healer Che’s smile matches his. “After this, you can have one drink with your friends and then it’s back to bed with you.”

Obi-Wan laughs again. He allows his joy to spread through the room so the others can share with him. It brings a smile to most of their faces. Councilor Windu, who has acted as a saber master and confidante during Obi-Wan’s apprenticeship, has an open and warm expression on his face.

“It is time,” Councilor Windu says.

There are formal words, spoken by the Councilors, by the Master, by the Padawan, and Obi-Wan treasures them. They are tradition with years of history behind them, and Obi-Wan is present and yet he is a part of every time this has happened in the past. He is Obi-Wan and he is Jedi.

It’s almost overwhelming.

A hand on his face returns him to the present.

Healer Che stands in front of him. Her eyes are kind as she looks down at him. “Padawan Kenobi,” she says, because the traditional words have been spoken and now, she is free to say something more personal. “You were sent to Naboo to face your Trial, and you faced an even greater one than we had planned.”

“The Force works in mysterious ways,” Obi-Wan murmurs.

“Indeed.” Healer Che brushes her thumb over his cheekbone. Her expression is solemn. “You were left on the Temple steps as an infant.” Her touch grows softer as Obi-Wan’s instinct is to flinch away from the words used to hurt him as an initiate. “You were not unwanted, my padawan. You were needed. And you will continue to be needed.”

Obi-Wan’s eyes fill with tears, not with the pain of old hurts but because this is a moment too large to contain within his body. He leans in until his forehead touches his master’s. “I will answer the Force’s call until I am no longer able.”

“I know.” Healer Che steps back. She is looking misty eyed as well. “For the last time, I call you Padawan Kenobi. Will you turn and show me your braid?”

Obi-Wan turns so she has access to the long braid he has cultivated since he was just shy of thirteen, and she chose him. He feels the heat from her hands and the pressure of a blade and then nothing.

“Healer Kenobi,” his former master says, and her voice wavers. “I have a gift for you.”

Obi-Wan turns to face her again. In her hand is coiled his braid. Red hair with beskar wire woven through it to represent his time on Mandalore. Beads to mark his apprenticeship and when he became a senior padawan. Threads to represent major missions. Melida/Daan. Mandalore. Doing relief work with Alderaan. His rotation at the retreat for elderly Jedi. An entire history in the palm of Healer Che’s hand.

His history.

She places the braid in Obi-Wan’s hand and closes his fist over it. “I am proud of you,” she says.

Anakin stays under the bed where no one can see him. The blankets from the bed hang down like walls. It’s dark in here, but it feels like a fort. And he isn’t scared of the dark. There are a lot of things he’s scared of. Being trapped in a sandstorm. Tuskens. Hutts. Slave denotators going off. Losing his mom.

It’s a long list. Thinking about it only makes him scared so he thinks about something else.

Above him, sleeping in the bed, is Master Jinn. Anakin doesn’t know what it means when his master is asleep and doesn’t wake up. On Tatooine, if a master couldn’t defend their property, they would lose it.

Master Jinn has been nice. Anakin doesn’t want to end up with a master who is mean.

When Master Jinn said he would take Anakin away from Tatooine, Anakin was excited. When Master Jinn said Anakin could be a Jedi, that was even more exciting. He was sad to leave his mom, but he was going to become a powerful Jedi and then come back and save her, so it was okay.

But now, he isn’t sure.

He’s pretty sure he failed the Jedi tests. Master Jinn said it was okay, and Anakin believes him, except Master Jinn is sleeping now. How is he supposed to make everything okay when he’s asleep?
