Flying the spaceship on Naboo was pretty cool. Going to the parade with Padmé was even better. But he isn’t on Naboo anymore. He’s on Coruscant at the Jedi Temple, and his master is asleep.

Anakin’s stomach rumbles. He tries not to think about it. When this place is quieter, he’ll sneak to the kitchen. There’s food there, all kinds, even fresh fruit. There’s water too, and it doesn’t cut off even if he fills an entire glass.

Anakin is bored hiding here all the time but at least he’s safe.

He hugs his knees to his chest and breathes as quietly as he can when he hears footsteps enter the room. There aren’t a lot of people who come in here which makes it a good place to hide. Anakin knows the footsteps of the people who usually visit. These ones are different.

He sees a pair of brown boots stop next to the bed.

“I’m sorry I couldn’t do more.”

Anakin doesn’t know this voice. The speaker sounds sad. Anakin doesn’t want him to be sad. He thinks about happy things. Hugs from his mom. When Watto lets him leave early. Playing stickball with his friends. Podracing.

“Are you—no. Huh.”

Anakin holds his breath as the boots shuffle backward. And then a hand lifts the sheet, and he sees a man’s face.

“Hello, there,” the man says.

Anakin squeezes his eyes shut. Maybe, if he wishes really, really hard, the man will forget he’s here.

“My name is Obi-Wan Kenobi,” the man says.

Anakin cracks an eye open.

The man tucks the sheet under the mattress to keep it raised and then he sits cross-legged on the ground. He offers Anakin a smile. He has the beginnings of a beard. It’s red, like the hair on his head. He has a nice smile, but he’s a stranger and Anakin knows better than to trust strangers.

“You don’t have to talk until you’re ready,” Obi-Wan says. “I didn’t talk when I first came to the Temple. I was an infant and so no one expected me to talk.” He smiles. Anakin thinks it’s a nice smile. “It’s a big place. It can be overwhelming if someone’s never been to it before.”

Anakin unfurls enough to nod his head. The Temple is big. There’s so many rooms and hallways and people. It took him a long time to find a good place to hide. He’s afraid if he leaves it, he won’t find his way back.

“Are you hungry?” Obi-Wan asks. He opens a pouch on his belt and produces several foil-wrapped items. He sets them on the ground between them. “I carry snacks with me, because sometimes I forget to eat. You’re welcome to any, or all, of those. I can always get more.”

Is this a trap? If Anakin takes it, will he owe Obi-Wan something? He doesn’t want to be in debt. That’s how people become slaves.

“I’m a healer,” Obi-Wan says, as if he doesn’t mind talking for both of them. “I was a padawan until I went to Naboo. I was supposed to help with an outbreak of the flu. And then the planet was invaded.” He looks up, probably at Master Jinn. “Do you know Master Jinn?”

Anakin nods.

“I don’t know him very well,” Obi-Wan says. “He is something of a legend at the Temple. He is one of the best negotiators we have, but his methods are unconventional. Did he go on Search? Is that why you’re here?”

Obi-Wan looks above him again, as if he’s searching for answers in the air. Anakin darts his hand out to grab one of the packages. He tucks his bounty away before Obi-Wan’s gaze returns to him.

Anakin isn’t sure if he likes the way Obi-Wan looks at him. He looks at him kinda like Master Jinn did, like he can see something that isn’t there.

“Would you like a bath?” Obi-Wan offers. “Or new clothes?”

Anakin almost says yes and then he shakes his head twice, as hard as he can. This is a trick.

“You don’t want food, you don’t want a bath, you don’t want clothes.” Obi-Wan’s face scrunches up. “A bed?”

Anakin points to the pillow and blanket he snuck down here. Obi-Wan feels sad again, like someone cracked open a black melon and it was full of sadness instead of stinky milk. Anakin tries to think happy thoughts again, but this time they meet a barrier and don’t go through.

“You’re naturally gifted,” Obi-Wan says. “And you have a kind heart. Will you let me be kind to you in return?”

Anakin thinks about it. Obi-Wan seems nice, and he wants to go with him, because all those things sound nice. A bath. Food. Clean clothes. But Anakin can’t. He can’t leave.

“I’m Master Jinn’s.” They’re Anakin’s first words to Obi-Wan, and he wants to snatch them back, but it’s too late. He already said them.

Obi-Wan’s forehead wrinkles as he frowns. “You’re Master Jinn’s padawan?”

Anakin shrugs. “I’m Master Jinn’s.”

Obi-Wan taps his fingers against his chin. “You want to stay here with him?”

Anakin nods.

“Alright. What if I go and get some food and some clean clothes and some washcloths and come back? Would that be okay with you?”

Anakin isn’t sure. He can’t leave, but can he accept gifts? “I don’t have any money.”

Obi-Wan is sad again. “That’s okay. You don’t need to pay for any of those.”

“Master Jinn is asleep.”

“He doesn’t have to pay for them either,” Obi-Wan says. “You’re at the Jedi Temple. We take care of those who stay with us and right now, you’re staying with us.”

“Okay,” Anakin says. And then, because his mom raised him right, “Please.”

#

Obi-Wan comes back like he promised. He goes to the table and sets down a pile of food, a stack of clothes, and a bowl with some water and cloths in it.

“What would you like first?” Obi-Wan asks.

“I can choose?” Anakin’s so excited, he forgets he didn’t want to talk.

“You can choose. And you can have all three.”

Anakin creeps forward. He snatches a roll from the offering of food and takes a bite. He tries to say something, but his mouth is too full. The roll has something sweet inside! He looks at the second half, still in his hand. There’s something purple and sticky in the middle of the roll.

“It’s blackberry jam,” Obi-Wan says. “Do they have blackberries where you’re from?”

Anakin shakes his head. He takes another roll and bites into it. This one has spiced meat and cheese. He moans and grabs the last surprise roll. He eats all three of them. His stomach hurts a little, but it’s worth it. “Clean now?”

“You have another choice,” Obi-Wan says. “You can clean yourself or I can clean you.”

“Myself,” Anakin answers quickly, before Obi-Wan can change his mind.

“Would you like me to leave the room?”

Anakin nods.

“I’m going to close the door,” Obi-Wan says. “When you’re all done, open it again, and I’ll come in.”

“What if I don’t?”

“Eventually, I’ll have to come in, because my patient is in here. I’ll knock first, and I’ll wait until I can’t.

“Okay.” Anakin spits on his palm the way he’s seen smugglers do, and then he holds his hand out to Obi-Wan.

Obi-Wan hesitates but he does shake Anakin’s hand. “Now, we both need to get clean.”

Anakin scrubs himself with the water. Master Jinn must be rich if he can afford for his slaves to wash with water. But if he’s rich, why couldn’t he buy a hyperdrive on Tatooine?

Anakin stashes some of the food under the bed. He munches on some orange sticks and then decides it’s kinda boring with just a sleeping Master Jinn for company. He opens the door so Obi-Wan knows Anakin is done washing.

“Obi-Wan.”

Anakin’s heart rate picks up at the sound of a new voice. He dives under the bed and pulls the sheet down to hide. Obi-Wan doesn’t feel as scared as Anakin, but he doesn’t feel right, either.

“Healer Che,” Obi-Wan greets. His voice is smooth and pleasant as if there’s nothing wrong.

“Don’t take that tone with me. I trained you, remember? Why did Master Jinn’s door open? I know he isn’t awake yet.”

“Ah.” Obi-Wan pauses and Anakin’s afraid he’s going to tell on Anakin. “Would you believe I didn’t feel like opening the door with my hand?”

There’s a long silence, but it feels weird. It’s like a conversation, except Anakin can’t hear any of the words. He doesn’t like it.

“I see,” Healer Che finally says. “I’ll tell the Council to call off their search.”

#

Anakin uses his finger to get the last of his oatmeal out of his bowl, because Obi-Wan says it’s rude to lick the bowl. Obi-Wan feels weird again today, but Anakin wants a full stomach before he asks about it. It’ll be easier to run if he isn’t hungry.

“You know I’m a healer,” Obi-Wan says as he hands Anakin an apple, already sliced into eight pieces so it’s easier for Anakin to eat. Last night, Obi-Wan gave him a baked apple with cinnamon sprinkled on it. Anakin doesn’t understand how that’s a treat and a raw apple is healthy, but he doesn’t want to ask in case Obi-Wan thinks he’s stupid.

Anakin eats a whole slice before he nods. “You help people here. Like Master Jinn.” A thought occurs to Anakin. “Are you his too?”

“Am I—no.” Obi-Wan’s eyes fill with sadness and it hurts, but then he blinks and he looks and feels calm again. “I’m a healer and he’s my patient. I would like it if you would be my patient too.”

“I’m not sick,” Anakin says. Sick slaves cost money instead of earning it and that’s a good way to end up dead or sold to the mines. He doesn’t know if they have mines on Coruscant, but he doesn’t want to find out.

“I’m glad but people can see healers even when they aren’t sick. I can help to make sure you don’t get sick.”

“You can?”

Obi-Wan nods. “I can help your body protect itself against the germs and viruses which make you sick.”

“I want that,” Anakin says.

“Have you ever been to a healer?” Obi-Wan asks.

“Not like you.”

“Alright. Would you like me to do the scan with my hands or would you like me to have a droid do it?”

“You have droids here?” Anakin perks up. Maybe he shouldn’t stay in this room forever.

“You like droids?” Obi-Wan smiles. “Let me get my helper. You hop up on the bed, I’ll be right back.”

Anakin does what he’s told and hops up on the second bed in the room. Obi-Wan brought it in when Anakin refused to leave the room except to use the fresher or to sneak into the kitchen when no one’s around. He thinks Obi-Wan knows when he leaves, but he hasn’t stopped him.

His legs are too short to reach the floor, so Anakin swings his feet. A bipedal droid with four arms enters. Obi-Wan follows with a cart full of things Anakin’s never seen before. He pulls his knees up to his chest as Obi-Wan closes the door.

“I am K-14,” the droid says. “You are my patient.”

“I’m Anakin,” Anakin says. “You’re going to help make sure I don’t get sick?”

“Yes. First, I am going to run a diagnostic.”

“A dia—what?” Anakin asks.

“A scan,” Obi-Wan answers. “He’s going to check your body to see if there are any hurts we should take care of before we start talking about boosters and vaccines.” Obi-Wan holds up a handheld device. “This is a medical scanner. K-14 is going to use it to check the inside and outside of your body. The scanner means he doesn’t have to touch you to do it.”

“You can see inside my body with that?” Anakin asks.

Obi-Wan points to the monitor on the cart he brought in. “You can watch. But first, can you stretch out on the bed? It will make the scan easier.”

Anakin stretches out on his back. He cranes his neck to see the screen, but Obi-Wan rolls the cart so he can see easier. K-14 turns the scanner on and then slowly moves it from Anakin’s head to his toes. As he does, a picture of a body shows up on the screen. Is that Anakin’s body? What do all the colors mean? Are they good colors? Bad colors?

“There are different settings,” Obi-Wan explains. He holds up a remote and points it at the screen. “I can look at your bones, your muscles, a full body image. It probably looks confusing, maybe even scary to you, because you don’t know what it means.”

“Do you?” Anakin asks.

“I do. I can tell you what I see, K-14 can tell you, or we can begin treating you.”

“I want to know,” Anakin says. “Will you tell me?”

Obi-Wan switches back to the image with no colors. Anakin thinks this is the bone one. Obi-Wan points to a darker spot near Anakin’s knee. “This tells me you broke your bone.”

“Podracing accident,” Anakin says. “It hurt a lot. Watto was really mad, because I cried and customers don’t like crying kids.”

Obi-Wan points to another spot, this one on Anakin’s left arm. “This was a broken bone as well.”

“I fell off a roof,” Anakin says. “Me and Kresh were playing smugglers and ‘forcement, and I tried to jump from one roof to another, but I didn’t make it.” He squints at the picture. “Is this like a map of my body? How’d you learn to read it?”

“It is like a map of your body. It shows me your present life and your past. And I learned to read it through many, many years of studying. There’s one more thing on this picture I want to talk about.” Obi-Wan taps a little shadow high up on Anakin’s leg.

Anakin squints and leans in. He wouldn’t have seen that if Obi-Wan didn’t tell him to look for it. He shrugs and looks over at Obi-Wan. “I haven’t studied body maps. Is it another broken bone?”

“It’s a chip,” Obi-Wan says.

Anakin looks again. That’s his slave chip? That tiny little shadow is his chip? He looks at his leg and pokes at his tunics. He can’t feel the chip.

“Anakin.” Obi-Wan’s voice is gentle and soft, like when Anakin’s mom would talk to some of the girls who worked for Gardulla. “This is a slave chip.”

Anakin nods.

“Are you comfortable answering some questions for me? I want to help you, but I need more information.”

Anakin isn’t sure. Obi-Wan has been nice, but what if he decides he doesn’t want to be anymore? What if he’s trying to lure Anakin away from Master Jinn? Anakin looks at the sleeping man on the other bed. He wishes Master Jinn would wake up. He’s alone here, and it makes him scared.

“What if I ask questions and you answer if you’re comfortable?”

Anakin shrugs. And then he nods.

“Okay.” Obi-Wan sits in the visitor’s chair. It means he’s shorter than Anakin which Anakin likes, even if it’s kinda like a trick. Obi-Wan is bigger than him even if he doesn’t look like it right now. Obi-Wan clears his throat. “What planet are you from?”

“Tatooine.” If all the questions are this easy, Anakin thinks he’ll answer them all.

“Did you meet Master Jinn there?”

Anakin nods. “Padmé was there too. They needed help.” Anakin wiggles on the bed, because this is a good story. And if Obi-Wan thinks he’s useful, he’ll keep looking after Anakin. “They didn’t have enough money for a hyperdrive so they bet on me in the podrace. And I won! And I won so big that Master Jinn got the hyperdrive and me. He says I’m going to be a Jedi, but he’s still sleeping, and I don’t think the others like me. Will you help me become a Jedi?”

“I’m going to help you be safe, healthy, and happy,” Obi-Wan says. “You said Master Jinn bet on your race?”

Anakin nods. “Master Watto owns a junk shop, and he doesn’t take Republic credits so Master Jinn couldn’t buy the part he needed. But Watto likes to bet so Master Jinn did that instead.”

“Watto owned you?” Obi-Wan asks. His voice is controlled, but Anakin can feel a lot of emotions in Obi-Wan’s head that are trying to escape. He doesn’t think Obi-Wan is actually calm.

Anakin nods. Is this the wrong answer? Is Obi-Wan mad at him? “You saw the chip on my body map.”

“I did. Anakin, when I first met you, you told me you’re Master Jinn’s. Do you think he’s your owner?”

“He won me,” Anakin says. “Watto gave him the detonator so I won’t blow up anymore, but I still have the chip.”

Obi-Wan takes a deep breath. Anakin pulls his knees up to his chest, because Obi-Wan feels angry now. But then he takes another breath, and the anger goes somewhere else. Anakin looks around as if he can see it.

“Anakin, I think there was some confusion. You aren’t a slave anymore. You don’t belong to Master Jinn.”

Anakin frowns. “So I’m alone? Who’s going to look after me?”

“You aren’t alone. You’re at the Jedi Temple on Coruscant, and we’ll look after you. But you aren’t a slave, Anakin. You’re free now.”

“What does that mean?”

“It means you have choices. It means you don’t have to stay in Master Jinn’s room.”

“Where would I stay?”

“The initiate dorms, I would think,” Obi-Wan says. “It’s a place where kids your age live. You wouldn’t be alone, and there would be kids for you to talk to and play with. During the day, you can go to classes and learn about things that interest you. There’s a commissary where you can eat each of your meals.”

That’s a lot. Anakin isn’t sure where to even start thinking about it.

“It also means I can take your slave chip out,” Obi-Wan says. “I’d like to introduce you to Wrirrra. He’s the clan-parent for one of the initiate clans. If you feel comfortable with him, he can help you pick out a bed and make some friends.”

“I want my chip out,” Anakin says. “And we can meet your friend. I want to start my Jedi lessons. Once I’m big and strong like Master Jinn, I’m going back to Tatooine to free my mom.”

“What?” Obi-Wan asks.

“My mom,” Anakin repeats. “She’s still on Tatooine. Master Jinn tried to win her too, but Watto said no. I’m worried about her.”

“I’m sorry you’re worried,” Obi-Wan says. “How about this. We take your chip out, I take a holo, and I find someone to bring it to your mom so she knows you’re at the Temple and happy. You can write her a note if you want.”

“Can’t write.” Anakin stares at his knees.

“Ah. Maybe that’s one of the classes we can start you with. Would you like to learn how to read and write?”

Anakin shrugs.

“We can make that decision later,” Obi-Wan says. “First, we have a chip to remove. It’s a small procedure, but it’s still surgery. Would you like to sleep through it?”

Anakin shakes his head as hard as he can. If he’s asleep, how does he know Obi-Wan will actually take it out? He wants to see it come out.

“Okay,” Obi-Wan says. “I will use a numbing agent, but it will feel funny.”

“Will it scar?”

Obi-Wan opens his mouth and then hesitates. “It doesn’t have to.”

“I want a scar,” Anakin says. He wants to know the chip is out, and he wants a reminder that it’s gone.

“Then you’ll have one,” Obi-Wan promises.

#

Obi-Wan is right. It does feel funny when he cuts open Anakin’s leg to remove the chip. It doesn’t hurt but he still feels it. He stays very still so Obi-Wan doesn’t cut more of him than he’s supposed to.

When it’s over, Obi-Wan puts a band-aid on the cut. And then he holds out a jar of lollipops. “Pick one,” he tells Anakin.

Anakin picks blue, because it’s the color of Obi-Wan’s eyes.

“This is long overdue,” Bail says as he sits across from Obi-Wan at a café. Bail has a fruit smoothie, because his med-droid has started making noise again about tattling on his health to Breha. Obi-Wan, of course, has a large iced-caf that probably has at least twice the recommended amount of caffeine in it.

Obi-Wan’s smile, charming and innocent enough to fool strangers, gets him all kinds of things. Extra caffeine shots is only one of them.

“Is it?” Obi-Wan asks. He blows on his drink before he seems to remember it’s an iced drink and not a hot one.

Bail wouldn’t say he and Obi-Wan are friends if anyone asked. Privately, in his head, he likes to think they’re, if not friends, then close acquaintances. Bail has always been active politically, even before he became a senator for Alderaan. But becoming a senator, and prince consort, has given him the means to achieve what had once seemed like far-off dreams.

In keeping with an Alderaanian tradition, Bail spent his first senate recess on an aid mission to Ryloth. Bail isn’t sure if Breha pulled strings or if the Jedi saw Bail’s mission and decided it would be simple to add their own team to his, but Bail gained two Jedi. One of them was apparently on Search which meant he was looking for any Force sensitives who wanted to train at the Coruscant Temple.

The second was Obi-Wan.

He was a solemn, almost twenty-year-old. A senior padawan, but if anyone thought padawan meant child or learner, they quickly revised their opinion after meeting Obi-Wan. His assistance on the mission was instrumental. He speaks Twi-lek which was useful when communicating with the natives of Ryloth, and he knows a lot about healing.

He also, which Bail didn’t realize at first, carries a lightsaber despite being a healer.

Unfortunately, his skills as healer and sabermaster were both needed.

Maybe Bail isn’t used to fighting alongside someone, and he created a relationship where there was none. But every time he asks Obi-Wan to meet him for a drink, Obi-Wan responds. If he’s on Coruscant, he almost always comes.

“You were knighted recently.” Bail nods toward Obi-Wan’s hair. There’s no long braid to be seen. Obi-Wan had hidden it when they were on Ryloth, but whenever they meet on Coruscant, he displays it proudly. For it to be missing means he graduated or whatever it is the Jedi call it.

“I am Healer Kenobi instead of Senior Padawan Kenobi.” Obi-Wan smiles and it’s almost too small to notice, but Bail can tell he’s pleased. Maybe even a little proud. It’s good. He should be. Despite living in sight of the Jedi Temple, Bail doesn’t know many actual Jedi. He knows the stories, the good ones and the bad ones. He knows the reports the Senate receives, but Obi-Wan makes the Jedi real for him.

“Congratulations are in order. And maybe a drink stronger than this.” Bail laughs as he drinks his smoothie. It’s quite good, a mix of berries native to Alderaan and thickened with a protein-heavy yogurt. Maybe he should try and get one every morning. Or make one at his apartment.

“You won’t like drinking with Jedi,” Obi-Wan says. His eyes dance with mischief. “We can filter alcohol. No hangovers.”

“I’m jealous.”

Obi-Wan’s smile brightens even more. And then he sobers. He looks around as if assessing their surroundings. He must decide their position is private enough, because he leans forward and says, “I do have a request. You are under no obligation to help. Any assistance you can provide, even a different contact, will be appreciated.”

“What can a junior senator do that the Jedi can’t?” Bail asks.

“When Master Jinn left Tatooine, he brought a boy with him. Master Jinn was able to secure his freedom but not his mother’s. I have heard,” again, Obi-Wan does a quick scan of the area, “that Alderaan may have experience in this area.”

Bail nods. It’s easy enough to confirm what Obi-Wan either suspects or knows. Alderaan prides itself on being a peaceful planet. They have prosperity, and they do their best to share that prosperity with others.

It’s done quietly, but Alderaan does have extensive contacts within the Freedom Lanes.

“The boy is…adjusting.” Obi-Wan frowns as if it hasn’t been a smooth adjustment. “But he worries for his mother.”

“Understandable,” Bail says, to both points. Moving from Tatooine to Coruscant would be an adjustment for anyone. Adding the fact that the boy is a former slave to the mix only complicates it. “Do you have anything to help with the search?”

Under the table, Bail feels Obi-Wan touch his knee. A moment later, a small pouch is placed on his thigh. Obi-Wan lowers his voice. “That is the boy’s slave chip. It should be enough to find his mother. I’ve included a few details on his life on the planet which should narrow it down even more. There’s also a holo of the boy. For his mother.”

“The holo will be given to her,” Bail promises. “And I’ll do everything in my power with regard to the second request.”

“Thank you.” Obi-Wan smile is genuine. And then it shifts into something playful as he leans back in his seat. “Tell me, how does a junior senator balance his obligations to his seat in government with his obligations as prince consort?”

“Are you asking how often I have sex with my wife?” Bail asks.

Obi-Wan gasps in mock-offense. “Such a scandalous topic of conversation, senator. I have sensitive ears, you know. I was raised in the Jedi Temple.”

Bail laughs at Obi-Wan’s antics and drinks from his smoothie again.

#

Chilea returns from her mission and reports directly to Bail’s office. He chose her because she’s one of his best operatives. She’s unassuming and she has a knack for blending into her environments so people rarely realize she’s somewhere she shouldn’t be.

“Senator,” she says with a curl to her words. She activates the anti-spy hardware he had installed when he took his position. Anyone who has his place bugged will assume he threw up the privacy shields so he could have a liaison.

“Success?” Bail asks. Despite the precautions, it’s best to keep the conversation as bland as possible.

Chilea saunters forward. She leans in to kiss him. He sighs into the kiss and pushes out from his desk so she can sit in his lap. This is not a precaution. This is simply a benefit to having an open relationship with his wife.

As they kiss, Chilea slips something into Bail’s pocket. And then she cups him between his legs and laughs as he tips his head back to draw in a sharp breath.

“Success,” Chilea answers. “And she’s staying to continue the success.”

Interesting, Bail thinks, even as Chilea tries to distract him by kissing his neck. He had made sure Chilea was empowered to offer Shmi Skywalker anything in Alderaan’s ability to give. He had thought she would relocate to Naboo, a nearby planet or even Alderaan which is both peaceful and close to Coruscant.

He finds he isn’t altogether surprised that she chose to stay on Tatooine and help others find their freedom. If her son is anything like her, the galaxy is fortunate to have him learning to be a Jedi.

Chilea pats the pocket with something in it. “That isn’t for you,” she tells him. And then she guides his hand between her legs. “This, however, could be.”

Bail laughs and decides his reports can wait. “Shall we take this to the bedroom and see if Breha is available?”

If she is, she’ll watch and maybe add some commentary or direction as Bail and Chilea bed each other. If she isn’t, they’ll send her a recording. Bail considers telling Obi-Wan about this arrangement the next time he teases Bail about being away from his wife. And then he laughs. Obi-Wan wouldn’t believe him. Or he would and then take it as a challenge to find a topic which will make Bail blush.

Best not to encourage him.

#

Bail meets Obi-Wan at a diner rather than their usual café. He nods politely to the Besalisk behind the counter and then works his way to the back of the diner where Obi-Wan already has a booth.

Bail tries not to judge, because he’s aware he comes from a prosperous planet, and, even for a citizen of Alderaan, he’s quite privileged, but this is not the sort of place he would frequent by choice. He’s almost certain two tables away there are two beings betting with spice as the stakes.

“I hope this doesn’t tarnish your reputation,” Obi-Wan says. He fiddles with the saltshaker, and Bail feels the hum as anti-eavesdropping technology kicks on. Apparently, Bail isn’t the only one made paranoid by Coruscant. “But this was a necessary change.”

“I agree,” Bail says. He looks Obi-Wan over. There are dark circles under his eyes, darker than the last time they met. “Would you like to talk about it?”

“About what?”

Bail is a senator. He knows better than to play these games with Obi-Wan, because Bail won’t win. “Anything you’d like. You seem troubled.”

“Master Jinn is still in his healing trance. Healer Che isn’t concerned, but the longer he’s in the trance, the longer his recovery will be once he comes out of it. He will have complications for the rest of his life.”

“But he’ll have a life,” Bail says.

“That’s true.” Obi-Wan nods as if he’d forgotten that he had already pulled off a miracle by saving the man’s life. “The boy…” Obi-Wan traces shapes on the table. “Qui-Gon is his biggest advocate. He’s stuck in a state of uncertainty until Qui-Gon is awake and can fight for him. Uncertainty is the last thing the boy needs.”

“He isn’t a Jedi?” Bail asks.

Obi-Wan’s lips quirk up as if he thinks Bail’s ignorance about the Jedi is amusing. “The Temple takes in younglings. We call them initiates. They’ve given basic training in the Force along with a more standard education. When they are chosen by a master, they become padawans and officially start on their journey toward what most people would call being a Jedi. The boy is an uncommon case.”

Obi-Wan pauses as a droid wheels over with a platter for each of them. Bail didn’t order, but Obi-Wan doesn’t find this abnormal, so he accepts what is more food than he has any hope of eating in one sitting. It’s fried and greasy and looks delicious. It also looks like it’ll earn him a scolding from his med-droid.

“Indulge,” Obi-Wan says as if he can tell what Bail is thinking. Obi-Wan’s burger has a fried egg on it so Bail suspects he should be pleased that his at least only seems to have onion straws.

“The boy?” Bail prompts.

“He’s older than the Temple normally accepts younglings,” Obi-Wan says. “And life has not been kind to him. His past, combined with the power he has, it could end poorly. There is a lot of debate on his future. It will remain uncertain until Qui-Gon wakes up.”

“In the meantime?” Bail asks sharply, more sharply than Obi-Wan deserves, but if the boy is being mistreated, Bail will throw the full power of Alderaan behind his complaint.

“I’ve argued that he should be treated as an initiate,” Obi-Wan says. “Having friends his age, learning to play and interact with others is important. He’s attending standard classes, because he didn’t have the education that a child on Alderaan, for example, would have. And he’s in very basic Force lessons. Control, mostly. Meditation. He’s being given the foundation he would have received if he came to us sooner.”

“But?” Bail asks. Something is clearly bothering the man in front of him.

“He’s a bright child, and he’s old enough to realize he’s different from the others. I worry for him.”

“Do you worry about him?” Bail remembers the comment about the Jedi fearing he might be dangerous. True, he had to read between the lines of Obi-Wan’s careful answers, but it’s there.

Obi-Wan takes the question seriously. He thinks it through as he takes a bite of his burger. After he wipes his face, prim and proper even in this diner, he says, “No. There are many paths besides the path of a Jedi knight. He will find a place within the Order.”

“But?” Bail asks again.

“I have concerns,” Obi-Wan says. He drags a fry through his ketchup, but he doesn’t eat it. “Master Jinn couldn’t free the boy’s mother because of circumstances. But there was no follow-up. There should have been. The Force has become…clouded recently, but Jedi are supposed to see the full picture. I’m concerned that we’re seeing part of it and then looking no further. It happened with the boy’s mother, and I think it’s happening again with the boy.”

Bail has concerns as well. If the Jedi are not as infallible as they appear, what are the safeguards in place? And where are the senators providing oversight and assistance? Their abilities make the Jedi seem larger than life, but they’re still beings, capable of mistakes. And the Order isn’t very large, not in comparison to planetary populations. Why should the Jedi bear the burden for righting the galaxy’s wrongs? It should be a collaborative effort.

“You saw,” Bail says. “You reached out about the boy’s mother and it sounds like you’re helping the boy as much as you’re able.”

“I never should have needed to.” Obi-Wan shakes himself. “Something to meditate on. As you said, we are correcting the missteps we made in this situation. It will have a happy ending.”

“How did you find this place?” Bail asks, recognizing when a change in conversation is needed.

Obi-Wan’s smile returns but now that he’s looking for it, Bail can see the shadows around it. “You wouldn’t believe me if I told you. But Dex makes the best comfort food on Coruscant. If you ever come here without me, don’t order. Let him make you a special. I’m convinced he has some Force sensitivity. There’s no other way he can know what someone needs.”

“Sounds like a puzzle,” Bail says.

“Are you now going to be a regular here?” Obi-Wan fiddles with the saltshaker again and the background buzz disappears.

“I am a man of the people,” Bail says.

“Alderaan has four different forks for formal occasions,” Obi-Wan says. “And you’re eating with your hands right now.”

“I’ll find a way to spin it,” Bail says. “I am, after all, a politician.”

“You’re a good man,” Obi-Wan says.

With a message from Shmi Skywalker sitting in his pocket, Bail can believe it. The trick, of course, is to continue to be a good man.

Mace almost misses when Obi-Wan was a padawan and intimidated by him.

“What part of limited missions do you not understand?” Obi-Wan, no, Healer Kenobi, demands.

He stands at the center of the Council Chamber, a tightly leashed maelstrom of fury. The worst part is, Mace knows he and his fellow Councilors are in the wrong. After Qui-Gon came out of his healing trance, it took nearly a year of physical therapy and healing sessions for him to regain his strength.

He’ll never have it completely back. The healers made it a condition of his return to the field that his missions would be carefully vetted by their team, and they had to give approval. Qui-Gon has chafed under the restrictions, and Mace suspects he’s ashamed a bit by having them.

It’s difficult to have a padawan like Anakin Skywalker, who is bursting with energy and excitement, and not be able to keep up with them. But Mace has knowns Qui-Gon for many, many years. He knew Qui-Gon would try and slip the restrictions. He should have kept a more careful eye on him.

“Tracking a bounty hunter, he was,” Master Yoda says. “Within his abilities, it was.”

“He should have transferred the mission once he knew how to follow the bounty hunter,” Healer Kenobi says. “Instead, you tell me he decided to hunt the hunter, and he’s now a prisoner on Geonosis.”

“Padawan Skywalker and Senator Amidala were dispatched to rescue him,” Saesee Tiin says.

“What?” Healer Kenobi asks weakly, as if he doesn’t have the energy for two fights.

Mace worries because they are about to place an even greater weight on young Obi-Wan’s shoulders. What is it Vokara asked Mace that time Obi-Wan dueled Yan Dooku? Why had the Force given her padawan so much endurance? For moments like this.

“Qui-Gon Jinn found something disturbing when he followed Jango Fett,” Plo Koon says. He waits until he has Healer Kenobi’s full attention to continue. “There is an army there.”

“What?”

“A clone army over a million strong. They were created for the Jedi, and they are ready to serve.”

“What?”

Mace watches Healer Kenobi try to process. He and his fellow Councilors have already gone through this, but Mace doesn’t have any tips on how to digest the information. An entire army, created in secret. And they will be used. Force help them all, but the clones will be used.

“Skywalker reported droid factories on Geonosis before he was captured,” Mace says. “We’re assembling a Jedi response team. You will select the healers that will accompany us.”

Healer Kenobi shakes his head. His confusion clears, and he sets his jaw in a familiar, stubborn, manner. “A Jedi response team? You mean a declaration of war.”

“Abandon our own, we cannot,” Master Yoda says.

Healer Kenobi swallows thickly. The pain is his eyes is kept carefully behind his shields. “Master Jinn, Padawan Skywalker, and Senator Amidala violated Geonosian law. If the Jedi interfere with Geonosian justice, we violate our neutrality.”

“Geonosian justice is execution via battle arena,” Saesee says.

Healer Kenobi closes his eyes. “I do not believe in the death penalty, but we are in the wrong here.”

“Senator Amidala was investigating on behalf of the Senate,” Ki-Adi Mundi says. “The Republic has authorized us to use the troops on Kamino to secure her rescue.”

“It will mean war.” Healer Kenobi’s words are barely above a whisper.

“According to the Senate, war has already been declared. We’re only responding to it,” Ki-Adi says.

Healer Kenobi locks his hands behind back. “I should select combat healers, then. Did Padawan Skywalker or Senator Amidala’s intelligence give any indication of the size or capability of the enemy’s forces?”

Mace suddenly remembers seeing the haunted look in Kenobi’s eyes after Melida/Daan. He remembers the quiet strength he showed after Mandalore. He remembers the fear after Naboo. He is uniquely trained for their upcoming challenges. Mace wishes he could shield him from it. He wishes he could shield them all from it.

#

Mace travels to Geonosis with Healer Kenobi. Despite being a healer, it was Kenobi they listened to when discussing strategy. Several Council members wanted to throw the entire weight of the Jedi Order and this new army at Geonosis.

Kenobi cautioned them against it. They have proof of an enemy growing where they didn’t see. They have evidence of an army raised for their side where they didn’t see. This war was inevitable. Perhaps even planned. A devastating victory on Geonosis won’t end it.

And, the painful truth is, the Jedi aren’t prepared. If they send a large force, they’re likely to lose them.

The number of Jedi are small, and the number of clone troopers is large. Their objective is to rescue their people, gain as much intel as they can, and then leave.

The Senate is already debating how to handle these new revelations. Mace left his former padawan, Depa Billaba in charge of coordinating with the Senate and relaying any relevant information to Mace and Yoda, who will be on the frontline on Geonosis.

From what Depa tells him, he should grow comfortable with the frontline.

The thought sickens him. He is a Jedi. He walks the thin line between light and dark, but he is a lightsider. He believes in the galaxy, and he believes in the Jedi. To lead an army, to fight a war…doesn’t that go against everything he is?

But what if the war is fought to protect the galaxy? Does that make it right?

Sometimes, Mace looks over at Healer Kenobi, and he sees the same questions on Healer Kenobi’s face.

#

Geonosis happens.

Mace kills Jango Fett.

Count Dooku escapes.

Hundreds die and Mace’s first thought is to be grateful Healer Kenobi argued against sending more Jedi. His second thought is that that means it’s clone troopers who died, not Jedi. They shouldn’t have died either.

Mace vows to himself that when he is given command, because he knows it is coming, it is inevitable, he will never value his life or his fellow Jedi’s lives over that of the men under his command.

It isn’t enough but everything is moving too quickly.

A thousand futures fade away and ten thousand more take their place.

#

Healer Kenobi stands at the center of the Council Chamber, and Mace at first thinks he’s stuck in possibilities of the future again. Or maybe he’s gone into the past. But no. This is a familiar scene, but it is a new one.

“We are all needed in these dark times,” Saesee says.

“Given command of the 7th Sky Corps, General Jinn has been,” Yoda explains.

Healer Kenobi’s hands twitch. “The healers have made it very clear—”

“They have,” Plo Koon interrupts, because they all know how long Healer Kenobi can go when he’s riled up. Still, Plo Koon is a brave man to interrupt Healer Kenobi. “Which is why we’re assigning you to General Jinn. Where he goes, you go. You will be able to monitor his health as needed, and he’ll be able to personally oversee the 212th. I will discuss the full details with you this evening.”

The full details? Mace isn’t aware of there being more details beyond that. They need Qui-Gon in the field, and the healers might finally revolt if that happens. Sending Kenobi along should appease them; though, Force knows, Qui-Gon will throw a fit about it. Mace will no doubt receive several angry comms in response.

At least it’ll be a break from angry comms about giving Skywalker a field knighting.

Mace still isn’t sure it was the right choice. Skywalker faced Dooku, and he held his own against the Fallen master. He lost a limb and didn’t give into anger. Does that make a knight? Does that make a Jedi? To lose and not give in to the dark side? To simply survive?

They need knights and masters to run the army they now command. Did they knight Skywalker because they needed him or because he was ready?

This situation is fucked.

And it’s only just beginning.

The first time Cody sees Kenobi is on Geonosis. Geonosis is a shitshow. No number of drills on Kamino or battle simulations could prepare them for it. It was fast, it was ugly, and there was death.

So. Much. Death.

The Prime taught them about death. How their brothers don’t leave them forever. They go marching beyond and one day, they’ll be together again. The Prime taught them to say the Remembrances. But so many brothers died, and there’s no complete casualty list.

There are brothers whose names won’t be said. Brothers who died and will be forgotten.

It is in this haze that Cody sees Kenobi. The man is a beacon. There is fire on his face and on his head. He is fury. He yells when Cody must keep quiet. He is pain when Cody must tuck his away.

He is a medic and suddenly everything makes more sense.

Medics are an anomaly. They are part of a battalion and yet they are beyond it. The chain of command exists, and they exist outside of it. They obey their general until they don’t and then their general must obey them.

Of course, Kenobi is a medic.

Who else could unleash a scolding on Cody’s general and get away with it?

#

Medics are an anomaly, but Kenobi is an anomaly amongst anomalies. Cody is a commander. He trained with the Prime. He is one of the top commanders in the GAR. He appreciates structure and order. He knows a battalion falls apart without it.

Kenobi disrupts the order.

It doesn’t escape Cody’s notice that the 212th is the only battalion with a Jedi medic. It doesn’t escape Fizz’s notice either. Fizz is the 212th’s chief medic. Or, he’s supposed to be? Because there is a Jedi who is not supposed to be here, and Fizz doesn’t know where the Jedi fits. Fizz doesn’t know where he fits.

It’s Cody’s responsibility to figure it out.

He doesn’t have a lot of time to think about it, because there is Kamino and then there is Geonosis and then they are mobilizing for their first campaign while still grieving for their first battle.

Cody has men to learn the names and strengths of, he has a general to learn, and a secondary general to become acquainted with. Handling interpersonal relationships fall to the side.

Until they’re two days out from their destination, and Cody finally has a moment to breathe. He allows himself one breath without worry or thoughts, and then he takes action.

“Medic Kenobi,” Cody greets.

Kenobi eats in the commissary with the vode. It makes him easy to find, and Cody stands next to Kenobi’s seat and waits for acknowledgement. Like the other Jedi Cody has met, Kenobi wears impractical robes. It’s too many layers and none of them useful. He wants his Jedi to at least wear armorweave if they insist on going without armor itself.

“Commander Cody.” Kenobi smiles at him. He’s made an effort to learn the men’s names. Once he knows a name, he uses it. Cody’s heard scuttlebutt that says he’s never forgotten one. Cody should advise him that there is no space for compassion in war. “How may I be of assistance?”

“Do you have any skill with mechanics? The caf machine in the med-bay is broken.”

“Broken?” Kenobi abandons his tray as if there’s an injured vod in the med-bay, not a broken machine. “And there hasn’t been a riot yet?”

Cody gives Kenobi a look that he hopes conveys that he would never allow something like a riot to take place on his ship. Kenobi’s lips twitch in a smile, as if he understands. Kenobi returns his tray to the kitchen and then falls into step next to Cody as they cross the ship to the med-bay.

Discreetly, Cody examines the man next to him. Like General Jinn and General Skywalker, Kenobi has a lightsaber clipped to his belt. Are medics trained like generals? He knows Fizz is more than capable with a blaster. It would make sense for Jedi to cross-train as well.

Rumor has it that General Skywalker and General Jinn battled Count Dooku on Geonosis. It’s how General Skywalker lost his arm and, from what Cody picked up from Kenobi’s anger, General Jinn was injured as well.

If Kenobi intends to be boots on the ground with the 212th, Cody will have to evaluate his combat skills. Is there a polite way to put a Jedi through a competency exam?

The doors to the med-bay slide open to welcome them. Kenobi goes straight for the break room to examine the caf machine. Fizz, who had been sitting behind the console near the entrance to the room, looks at Cody with something close to betrayal.

“Speak with him,” Cody says. Communication could have solved this problem from the beginning, but Kenobi is difficult to pin down. He sits in the commissary long enough to eat, but he doesn’t linger much longer than that.

And when he’s in the med-bay, he has his own room. Fizz says it’s some kind of research lab. He’s jealous and bitter at the same time. When Kenobi isn’t attending to his own basic needs or attending to the patients they already have, he is in the lab. But now, Cody has brought him to Fizz.

“About what?” Fizz hisses. He looks toward the break room as if Kenobi will overhear them.

Kenobi comes out a moment later. He looks from Fizz to Cody and then raises his eyebrows. “The caf machine is missing a screw.”

“How strange,” Cody says. He pulls the small metal screw from one of the pouches on his belt. “I have it right here.”

“Indeed.” Kenobi holds out a hand and the screw tugs itself free from Cody’s fingers and floats into Kenobi’s waiting palm. He looks between Cody and Fizz again before he returns to the break room.

“Are you looking to be decommissioned?” Fizz demands.

Cody waits, patiently. After another few minutes, Kenobi pokes his head out of the room. “Are you going to join me? Both of you, of course.”

Fizz gives Cody what would have been a threatening look if Cody hadn’t been raised by Alpha-17, the Prime, and an assortment of bounty hunters. When they join Kenobi in the break room, there are three cups of caf at three of the chairs. None of the chairs are situated as to have the seated individual leave their back to the door.

So, Kenobi has good observational skills. Or he knows what to expect from men trained for war.

“What would you like to discuss?” Kenobi asks. He looks at Cody, but Cody remains blank-faced, because he isn’t here to talk. Kenobi’s gaze slides to Fizz.

“What are my failings?” Fizz asks. He tips his chin up, but it’s false bravado, and if Cody can see through it, he suspects Kenobi can as well.

“Your failings?” Kenobi’s puzzlement rings true. “Why do you think you have failed?”

“No other battalion has a Jedi medic assigned to them,” Fizz says. “I had the best scores on Kamino. I was hand-chosen for this assignment.”

Kenobi stares long enough that Cody’s feelings the first twinges of discomfort. And then he swears, sharply, in Mando’a, which catches Cody off guard. Kenobi rubs his forehead and looks less like a Jedi and more like a human. “We’re moving so quickly we can’t even communicate. And the war is only at its start.” He shakes himself as if he’d been speaking his thoughts without meaning to. “I apologize, Medic Fizz. I was not assigned here because of any failing of you or any of the other medics assigned to the 212th. What do you know about your general?”

“Humanoid,” Fizz says. “Exiting his prime age and entering his middle age. His physical activity is restricted due to damage to his left lung and a minor heart issue.”

Kenobi scoffs. “Minor heart issue? Is that what they’re calling it?”

Fizz straightens up as if he recognizes Kenobi as an ally, not an enemy. “Do you know more than what is in his public file, sir?”

Kenobi waves off the title. “I’m not a sir. And what do you mean, his public file? You are the head medic, and they gave you General Jinn’s public file?” Kenobi swears again, and it’s definitely Mando’a. He runs a hand through his hair, still the color of fire, still bright amongst the neutral grays and blues of the starship. “General Jinn battled the Sith known as Darth Maul on Naboo. During the course of the fight, he was injured.”

Kenobi’s gaze is somewhere above Cody and Fizz. There’s a blankness in his eyes and a flatness to his tone, as if he’s reciting facts. It’s a strategy Cody has used when trying to mask his feelings. He is a soldier, he can give a report.

“His left lung was punctured by a lightsaber,” Kenobi says. “The shock to his body disrupted his cardiovascular system. The only reason he is alive is because I was close enough to reach him before his injuries claimed his life. I—” Kenobi purses his lips. “I won’t bore you with the details. I stabilized Mast—General Jinn. He entered a healing trance. After three months, his body could support exiting the healing trance. It took a year of conscious recovery and physical therapy for him to be approved for missions again. But he will be on restricted duty for the rest of his life. His lung capacity is reduced and when he’s under great physical stress, he experiences cardiac arrhythmia.”

“He what?” Fizz demands flatly.

Kenobi drains the rest of his caf. Cody starts a second pot, because he has a feeling they’ll need it.

“To address an earlier point, the 212th is the only battalion to have a Jedi healer, because it’s the only battalion led by a general who needs one.” Kenobi pinches the bridge of his nose. “If I had my way, General Jinn would not be on the frontlines of this war. Since he is, I am here as well. I am not here because there is something deficient with you or the other medics. And I’m not here, because I’m the only one who can treat him. I’m here, because the Council didn’t want another lecture from me, and because I have a better chance at stopping General Jinn from overextending his limits than anyone else.”

“We’ll do it together,” Fizz says.

#

The night cycle before they’re expected to reach their destination, Cody finds Medic Kenobi standing by one of the star ports. He stares out into space as if there’s something heavy weighing on his mind.

Cody stands next to him but doesn’t speak. He’s available but he won’t push.

“You and your brothers were raised for war,” Kenobi says. “Was Geonosis your first exposure?”

They weren’t only raised for war, they were bred for it. Two million clones crafted into soldiers. There was one exception, Boba. He was the Prime’s favorite. He was special. He wasn’t given to the Jedi. Cody heard rumors he was on Geonosis. He wonders if Kenobi knows what happened to the kid. And then he remembers Kenobi asked him a question. “Outside of sims, yes.”

“It’s different when it’s real.”

Cody nods. “It is.” They were pushed hard in their simulations, and he lost brothers on Kamino, but it was nothing like Geonosis. There was still the thin veil of safety and home. Geonosis was death. There were no second chances. There was no ending the sim.

He thought he was ready.

“You’ll never be ready,” Kenobi says, as if he plucked the thought from Cody’s mind. “I went to my first warzone when I was thirteen. Most of my patients were younger than I was. It was—” Kenobi blinks back tears. “It was the worst thing I have ever experienced. It didn’t make it better when I went to my next warzone.”

Kenobi doesn’t need to be comforted like a shiny, but Cody is tempted to rest a hand on his shoulder anyway. He falls into parade rest, instead. “We were made for this. We won’t disappoint.”

“Made for this,” Kenobi murmurs as if speaking to himself. “You were, weren’t you. You are a solution to a problem the Republic didn’t know it was going to have. Which does, of course, beg the question. Who knew?”

“Sir?” Cody asks.

It’s a sign of Kenobi’s distraction that he doesn’t brush off the title. “Someone had to know. But who sees a war coming and builds an army instead of trying to deescalate the situation? Who knew about the Separatists and the droid factories? Who knew about Kamino? And why didn’t we?”

Cody leaves Kenobi to his thoughts, but he makes a mental note to do some investigating of his own. He and his brothers were raised for war. They were made for the Jedi. So why, then, were the Jedi so surprised to see them?

#

Cody stands at his general’s side, his expression carefully neutral as Kenobi and his general…discuss the deployment plan.

“You are the medic. You belong in the med-bay,” General Jinn says.

Kenobi’s expression is as placid as Cody’s, and his tone is artificially light as he says, “I am a medic, and my place is with my battalion. If this campaign is being conducted on the planet, then I will be on-planet as well. This is non-negotiable.”

General Jinn sucks in a breath, but he waves his hand in agreement. “Fine.”

#

Cody doesn’t see much of Kenobi during the campaign. Cody is on the ground, at General Jinn’s side or leading strike forces. Kenobi remains at base camp with the med-tent.

When Cody’s at base camp, it’s to grab something in the mess or to fall face first onto his cot. He doesn’t spend much time in the med-tent, and Kenobi rarely spends any time outside of it. According to Fizz, Kenobi contributes just as much, if not more, than any other medic. He can do things with the Force the vode can’t, but he doesn’t shy away from tasks like cleaning bedpans or restocking supplies.

The few times Cody does see him, Kenobi looks…odd. Bulkier, somehow. He’s still in his Jedi robes, even though they billow and get in the way of fighting. But there’s something about him that isn’t the same as when they’re on The Negotiator. No, Cody shouldn’t call their ship that. The name isn’t official.

It was submitted as a joke, after the third time Kenobi had politely told General Jinn that something was non-negotiable.

Cody doesn’t like that they went into their first battle with their ship unnamed. If it’s bad luck for shinies to go into battle without a name, surely it’s the same for a starship.

Tonight, Cody doesn’t look for Kenobi. In fact, he avoids the med-tent entirely. Their latest push had been…disastrous might be too light a word to describe it. Their losses were heavy, and they hadn’t even gained much ground.

Waxer joins Cody on the ridge. He sits down next to him and stares out at where they can see the flash of a firefight in the distance. Cody turns to fix Waxer with a hard look. He didn’t come out here alone for the company.

“Don’t panic, Commander,” Waxer says.

Cody’s too weary for panic. “What happened?”

“Kenobi took a squad to the canyon. General Jinn cleared it, and it was volunteers-only, but I wanted you to hear it from me or the general personally. He—” Waxer hesitates. “Kenobi said he could still feel some of the vode in the Force.”

“We had to retreat,” Cody says. It was the only way to make sure they all didn’t end up dead.

“No one’s questioning you or General Jinn’s orders,” Waxer says. “But if Kenobi can bring even one of them home, it’s worth him going, right?”

“It is.” Cody bows his head. “I should catch some sleep. Wake me if there are any developments.”

#

Cody doesn’t need Waxer to wake him. He wakes at dawn, and he exits his tent in time to see the slow procession of men into camp. Some of them are limping, some of them are barely dragging themselves forward, and some are relying on the help of others, but there are far more than the squad Kenobi set out with.

Kenobi himself leads the procession. He looks as exhausted as the ones who had been in yesterday’s battle. He staggers forward and gratefully slumps into General Jinn’s arms. The general seems surprised at first, but his expression softens into something close to fond.

“You did well,” General Jinn says. “It’s time for you to rest.”

As General Jinn half-escorts, half-carries Kenobi toward the officers’ tent, Cody steps up to herd his vode to the med-tent.

He catches one of his vod, a shiny who isn’t shiny anymore, his armor dented and cracked and dirty with soot and blood. His vod tries to jerk back when he realizes who he collapsed on. “Sir,” he slurs.

“At ease,” Cody says. He helps him into the med-tent and then finds an empty bed for him.

Fizz and the other medics exclaim at the influx of patients. He knows they’re grateful to see so many alive, even if it will stretch their space and their resources to care for all of them. Knowing there aren’t enough hands for all the patients, Cody helps his vod remove his armor.

“What’s your name, verd?”

“Hopper, sir.” He winces at the light in the tent. “Took a hit to the bucket, and I was out cold. Woke up and I was surrounded by bodies.” He swallows thickly. “And then our baar’ur arrived. He healed them, sir. Vode with shrapnel in their backs and rocks crushing their legs. He healed them enough to walk back. Clash is still there, sir. Baar’ur said he’s returning as soon as he’s rested enough. We can’t let the Seppies advance. Not until baar’ur’s brought our vode home.”

“Understood,” Cody says.

“No!” Hopper grabs Cody’s wrist. “I mean it. We have to hold the line. They trust us to come back for them.”

“I understand,” Cody says, softer this time. He runs a hand over Hopper’s forehead. “I’ll coordinate with the general. You be good for Fizz and his team.”

“Is that an order, sir?” Hopper smiles, lop-sided, and already drifting off.

“Damn right it is.”

Cody leaves the med-tent and enters the command tent. He isn’t surprised to see Waxer already there or for General Jinn to join a moment later. Cody points to the map. “I know how we can defend the canyon.”

#

By the end of the campaign, the 212th has a new squad, the Baar’ur Squad. They go out, after a battle, and search for survivors. They can’t save everyone, but they care enough to try, and it gives Cody hope that this war can be won, and that he won’t lose all of his vode along the way.

Rex hurries to the training room and hopes there will still be a good place left to watch the fight. Skywalker stuck him with a bunch of paperwork and then disappeared to prepare for his spar. And while the general can get away with shirking his administrative duties, Rex can’t.

The training room is packed with vode from the 212th and the 501st. The two battalions spend a fair amount of time together, because of the relationship between their two generals. Rex appreciates the opportunity to see Cody in person, even if the commander puts Rex through his paces like they’re still on Kamino.

It isn’t a vode tournament that has everyone gathered here, though. General Jinn arranged a spar between Rex’s general and Cody’s baar’ur. Rex didn’t even realize Kenobi carried a lightsaber, let alone knows how to use it.

Rex elbows his way through the crowd until he finds Cody. Maybe it’s an abuse of privilege to claim the spot next to him, but Rex earned his captaincy, and there are so few damn perks in this war, he’ll take whatever ones he can find.

Cody stands with perfect posture, as stiff as a fucking corpse. Most people would look at him and see a dignified commander. Rex knows better. Cody falls back on regs when he doesn’t want to show what he’s thinking. Normally, he’s hiding anger, but Rex thinks he detects a bit of worry hidden behind Cody’s carefully blank face.

It makes sense. Rex’s general is something else, and that isn’t a biased opinion. In terms of raw power, Rex isn’t sure he’s seen a Jedi stronger than his general. He’s heard the stories about the Baar’ur Squad. Kenobi has guts and he has honor, but those don’t make someone a duelist.

Cody clenches and unclenches his fists as if he wishes he has his blasters on him. As if he wishes he could step in for his baar’ur.

There is friendly competition between the 212th and the 501st. They pit themselves against each other, brag about their kill counts, brag about their Jedi, anything and everything is fair game. But this feels wrong. Rex doesn’t have anything against an easy victory, the war has taught him to appreciate wins no matter how they happen, but Cody’s distress is leaking everywhere like he’s the Force sensitive one.

“I’ve never seen him use it,” Cody says quietly, as Kenobi unclips his saber from his belt.

“He doesn’t miss with a blaster.” A vod Rex doesn’t recognize comes to stand on the other side of Cody. He gives Rex a two-fingered wave. “Shortstack. I’m part of the Baar’ur Squad. His aim would make any sniper proud.”

“Have you seen him use the saber?” Rex asks.

Shortstack shakes his head. “We do stealth missions and recovery. A glowing light stick isn’t very subtle.”

Cody clenches his jaw this time and Rex swears he hears his teeth grind together.

“He wouldn’t carry it if he didn’t know how to use it,” Rex reasons.

“Is this a punishment?” Shortstack asks. “General Jinn was ticked off after Baar’ur put him on bedrest.”

“You think this is a public humiliation?” Rex asks.

Shortstack doesn’t answer, but his eyes do narrow as if he’s contemplating a response if it is. Rex leaves him to his revenge fantasies knowing they’ll only ever be that. Cody might have a soft spot a dozen kliks wide for Kenobi, but General Jinn is his general. If he ordered Cody to wipe the floor with Kenobi, Cody would do it.

Like a good fucking soldier.

Rex schools his face into something less mutinous. If Cody wasn’t so preoccupied, he would have already called Rex out on his expression. Cody has a sixth sense for vode who doubt their generals or their mission, and he gives them no leeway.

They were made for the Jedi.

But does that mean the Jedi can do no wrong?

Cody elbows Rex sharply in the gut.

“Sorry, sir,” Rex mutters. Busted.

He redirects his attention to the two Jedi standing in the sparring ring. Kenobi is finishing a series of stretches which show off a surprising flexibility, but there’s nothing intimidating about being able to do a split. Well, Rex’s balls want to climb up into his body because that looks like it hurts, but Skywalker is unimpressed.

“I’ll go easy on you,” Skywalker promises, jovial as he finishes his own warm-up. “And I’ll give you a lollipop afterward.”

“Lollipops are for visits to the med-bay,” Kenobi responds. “Should I be worried at how much damage you’re intending to do?”

“What?” Skywalker loses his teasing smile. “I’m not going to hurt you, Obi-Wan. This is a friendly spar.” Skywalker glances at General Jinn as if looking for confirmation.

Kenobi follows his gaze and huffs at the sight of General Jinn standing as he watches them. “Will someone please get General Jinn a chair?”

“I don’t need a chair,” General Jinn says.

“And I don’t need to spar with Anakin,” Kenobi responds pleasantly.

There’s a silent battle of wills before it’s General Jinn’s turn to huff. He sits in the procured chair. Rex whistles lowly. “You call your ship The Negotiator?”

“We never said who we named it after,” Cody says.

Fizz steps up next to General Jinn. The medic looks irritated, but Rex is pretty sure that’s his default expression. “This is a friendly spar. Sabers will be set to their lowest setting. The spar ends when a “fatal” wound is landed, when one combatant yields, or when I call the match. Understood?”

“Understood,” Kenobi says. Skywalker echoes him a moment later.

Fizz waves his hand. “Do your thing, then.”

Kenobi chuckles. “Do your thing? Where’s the respect, Fizz? Lightsaber combat is a time-honored—”

Kenobi doesn’t finish because Skywalker ignites his saber and initiates the attack. Kenobi ignites his own saber in time to block Skywalker’s swing. Their blades crackle as they touch. Kenobi spins away in a graceful movement to disengage.

“As I was saying,” Kenobi flicks a mock-irritated look toward Skywalker, “Lightsaber combat is a time-honored tradition of the Jedi Order.”

One of the vode groans loudly. “End it, please General Skywalker! We didn’t come here for a lecture.”

“I know your voice, Cheeks,” Kenobi says pleasantly. “I’m hurt you don’t at least pretend to share my interests. And that you’re betting against me.”

“I’m betting on you!” A different vode calls out.

“Thank you, Gunner.”

“I’ll haul you to med-bay when it’s over!”

Kenobi laughs again. “Where’s your faith, Tank?”

“What’s happening?” Rex asks quietly. Is Kenobi planning to talk Skywalker into submission?

“I have no fucking clue,” Cody answers. He’s practically vibrating with the effort to contain his fury, and Rex bets half of it is not knowing what’s going on and the other half is his worry for his baar’ur.

Skywalker doesn’t have the patience for the conversation, and he charges again. The first time, Skywalker had held back, because Kenobi had been talking. It was a gentle start to the spar. This second pass isn’t a full-out attack, but there’s more behind it.

Once again, Kenobi meets Skywalker’s blade. The first swing, the second, and then the follow-through.

Surprise trickles through the room. Rex hadn’t expected Kenobi to go down in the first minute, but he hasn’t even shown weakness yet.

“Hmm, I have to concede you had a point,” Kenobi says. He looks to General Jinn long enough to make it clear who he’s talking to before he focuses on Skywalker again. “They all think I carry a saber for the aesthetic.”

Kenobi’s in Jedi robes, but Rex can see the high collar of the vode blacks underneath it. He has a neatly trimmed beard and his hair, quite long, is pulled into a topknot to keep it out of his face during the fight. Rex isn’t sure anyone has ever looked at Kenobi and thought, yes, he dresses this way for the aesthetic.

“Take this seriously!” Skywalker demands. He attacks with aggression and it lends even more power to his moves.

Rex winces as Kenobi blocks and defends. He knows from experience how much of an impact Skywalker can pack when he wants to. But Kenobi doesn’t buckle. He doesn’t even seem to be straining as he counters every powerful strike.

“What is this?” Rex asks Cody.

Cody doesn’t answer, because Skywalker darts in and out, trying to break through Kenobi’s guard and then he does one of his fancy flips. He should land a blow to Kenobi’s exposed back, but Kenobi’s saber is there to meet the strike before it can land.

“The fuck?” Rex asks.

Rex has seen his general on the battlefield. He is like a storm on Kamino, one of the bad ones where the entire building shook and every roll of thunder made Rex vibrate in his boots. Skywalker is a whirlwind, and he cuts swaths through droids as if they’re flimsi. But against Kenobi, there’s no opening. Every time Skywalker thinks he has one, Kenobi stymies him.

Rex hasn’t seen a Jedi fight like this before. He’s been on enough joint missions with the 212th to understand General Jinn’s style. And every vode reviewed the footage from Geonosis to see how the Jedi fought. But Kenobi didn’t fight on Geonosis and none of the other Jedi did this.

“Healer Kenobi is a student of Soresu,” General Jinn explains for the benefit of the vode as Kenobi and Skywalker continue to circle each other. “It’s known for being the most defensive of the lightsaber forms. I once witnessed Healer Kenobi hold his own against an older, more experienced opponent for hours.”

“Hours?” Rex echoes.

“Oh,” Cody says softly. “This isn’t about Kenobi.”

Rex waits but Cody doesn’t expand on his thoughts. After another ten minutes, Rex doesn’t need him to, because he sees it too. They’re not even half an hour in, and Rex’s general is slipping. This isn’t a training exercise for Kenobi, it’s for Skywalker.

Kenobi defends against Skywalker’s onslaughts without tiring. With each rebuff, Skywalker grows more manic. He becomes more powerful, but he also gets sloppy. He enters a combo which Rex has seen devastate droid ranks at the end. Rex isn’t sure what it will do to Kenobi.

When Skywalker brings his saber down with all the accumulated force of his attack, Kenobi meets it, and then he slides out from underneath it. Skywalker stumbles forward, carried by the momentum, and Kenobi holds the tip of his saber at Skywalker’s throat.

“I yield,” Skywalker says.

Kenobi powers down his saber. He offers his hand to Skywalker. Rex holds his breath and wills his general to set his pride aside. After a long moment, Skywalker clasps Kenobi’s hand and allows Kenobi to pull him to his feet.

“Good match,” Skywalker says tersely and then he strides out of the room.

Kenobi turns on his heels to give General Jinn a significant look and then he follows Skywalker out.

#

Rex’s general is young. It doesn’t bother Rex as much as maybe it should. Rex is also young, and yeah, Skywalker is impulsive and his first reaction is usually to blow things up, but Rex understands that. They’re well-matched.

It’s why he knows whatever shit General Jinn just pulled wasn’t helpful.

It isn’t his place to correct a general, though, so he follows Cody out of the training room. They get caught in the throng for a bit, and they listen to the vode gossip about the fight. There’s a lot of awe for Skywalker, because he’s always impressive to watch. But there’s just as much for Kenobi.

Baar’ur Squad smugly brags about their squad leader until a few fights break out as the vode decide to settle who’s best amongst themselves rather than comparing Jedi.

Cody escapes to the Officers’ Lounge. Rex tags along. Once they’re inside with the door closed, Cody exhales slowly.

“That was fucked up,” Rex says as he goes to make a cup of caf for each of them. “I don’t know how good Kenobi actually is, but his strength is Skywalker’s weakness. It was a lopsided match.”

“General Jinn said Baar’ur can spar for hours,” Cody says.

Rex doesn’t comment on the name. It doesn’t surprise him that the 212th have adopted Kenobi as one of their own, but he is surprised Cody has as well. Cody likes his regulations and his rules, everything to be in a careful, precise order. Folding a Jedi into the vode? That isn’t nice and neat. But a Jedi who goes out and brings as many vode back after battle as he can? Rex understands where the loyalty comes from.

When Rex brings over the caf, he nudges Cody away from the console. “I’m not as good as Fives, but I’m not bad. Let me look.”

Rex connects to the Archives. He sifts through the publicly accessible material. It takes some time, but he figures out the Temple hosts, or at least used to host, Jedi tournaments. It’s something the vode did on Kamino, both friendly and a competition at the same time.

There are records of the tournaments and there’s even video of some of the more infamous ones. The file Rex wants is locked. After a moment, he realizes why.

“Well, shit.” Rex turns the screen toward Cody. Under the date of the tournament took place, there are the combatants: Master Yan Dooku versus Padawan Kenobi. If the holonet knew there was footage of a baby Jedi fighting the Separatist General…

“Padawan?” Cody asks. He does a bit of investigating of his own. He looks at Kenobi’s birth year and then the date of the tournament. “He fought Dooku at fifteen?”

Rex submits a request to the Temple Archives for permission to view the video. Part of it is curiosity. Part of it is strategy. Count Dooku has given them trouble since he was revealed to be on the side of the Separatists. Maybe Kenobi’s fight has some kind of weakness they can exploit.

The other videos aren’t locked so Rex and Cody sip their caf and watch the Jedi compete against each other. They’re so engrossed in their video, they call out a distracted greeting when the doors open but don’t turn to see who it is.

“What are you—oh.” Kenobi sounds puzzled as he leans over their shoulders to see the screen. “Old tournament videos?”

“You aren’t in very many of them,” Cody says.

“I’m not a fighter,” Kenobi says. He lifts Cody’s cup off the table and makes another pot of caf. “I only entered if my friends bugged me enough or if Councilor Windu suggested it.”

“General Windu?” Cody turns in his chair to look over at Kenobi. “I thought you trained with the healers.”

Rex will go to his grave with this, but Cody’s adorable when he’s confused. His forehead scrunches like he’s offended there’s knowledge out in the world that he doesn’t know.

“The Jedi are a community,” Kenobi says. He pours himself a cup of caf and refills Cody’s. He hands Cody his cup back and then joins them at the table. “Healer Che taught me we’re at our best when we work together. I would not be the healer I am without her. But saber work isn’t her strength, so she had me learn from our battlemaster as well as Councilor Windu.” Kenobi smiles at some distant memory. “I’m proficient with Soresu. Councilor Windu challenged me to learn some more offensively-minded forms so I was well-rounded.”

“And now you’ll train General Skywalker?” Rex asks, trying to understand.

Kenobi’s lips press together in a frown. He tries to cover for it by sipping his drink, but Rex noticed. And if Rex noticed, Cody certainly did as well.

“The role of a teacher is to know when something is beneficial and when it isn’t,” Kenobi finally says. “Did you ever train your brothers?”

Cody nods.

“Then, you know. There is a certain amount of diversity needed in training so there are no obvious gaps. But there is also a certain amount of specialization. Anakin will never be defensively-minded. It’s best for him to lean into his strengths. For me to train him in Soresu would be an exercise in frustration. For both of us.”

Rex can’t help but notice the way Kenobi’s expression softens when he says Skywalker’s name. Or that he calls Skywalker by his first name. “You know him.” And then, before Kenobi can deflect, “Well. You know him well.”

“I met Anakin when he first came to the Temple.” Kenobi sips his caf as he determines how much he’s going to share. “I’m older than him, enough that friendship isn’t natural. I see him as something like a younger brother, I suppose.”

“You’ve never sparred with him before,” Cody says.

“Most people don’t ask the healers for a spar.” Kenobi grins and the smile reaches high enough to light up his eyes. “That’s not the kind of relationship we have. Anakin’s journey has been a bit unorthodox. I’ve tried to support him as best I can. Today was a misstep. I didn’t realize we’d have such a large audience.”

“It wasn’t your decision,” Cody says, loyal as always. Rex, because he’s self-aware, can recognize that he’s jealous. He knows what it’s like to be found worthy by Cody. He still remembers the first time Cody hauled him off the ground and promised to help Rex train until no one would look at his hair, only his performance scores.

Like all of the vode, Cody is a mean son of a bitch, and he’s difficult as fuck to please, but once you’re on his good side, you’re there. Cody’s loyalty is hard-earned, but it’s worth more than any promotion or commendation Rex has received. He hopes Kenobi realizes what a gift he’s earned.

“I could have said no,” Kenobi says. He runs a hand through his hair, loose now that the spar is over. “What’s done is done. Anakin and I spoke. He knows it wasn’t a test.”

The doors open and Skywalker storms into the room. “Tell me the truth, was it a test?”

Kenobi’s smile is bitter. “Or perhaps, he doesn’t. Anakin, it wasn’t a test.”

If anything, Skywalker’s expression grows darker. “Then it was about Dooku.”

“What?” Kenobi asks.

Next to Rex, Cody curls his hand around his cup of caf. His other hand rests below the table, ready to draw. Years of training make Rex want to respond to the tension and his vod’s reaction, but he doesn’t. This is the Officers’ Lounge. They aren’t shinies brawling at every perceived slight.

“Your famous fight.” Skywalker’s expression is a riot of emotion. Anger. Embarrassment. And, most prominent, hurt. “You fought Master Dooku for hours. And you were only a padawan. Was today supposed to be a lesson? A scolding?” Skywalker rubs his prosthetic, the one he gained after his own bout with Count Dooku.

Rex wasn’t on Geonosis, but he heard about Skywalker’s run-in with the Count. Could the war be over already if Skywalker had struck him down on Geonosis? Rex isn’t sure. But he is sure that his general will lose a few night’s sleep thinking about it and blaming himself.

“Anakin, the two fights weren’t similar,” Kenobi says.

“Because yours was successful?”

Kenobi arches his eyebrows. “If you watch the video, you’ll see that I lost the spar against Master Dooku. And that’s the key difference. I went up against a master of the Order in a friendly spar. I didn’t enter the fight expecting to win. I wanted to see how long I could hold out. He defeated me, because even a mountain cannot stand forever. But you, Anakin. You battled a Sith.”

“I wasn’t good enough.”

“In that fight, no. But you lived which means you have the time to improve. Count Dooku was preparing for this war long before we knew it existed. We’re playing catch-up, but there are more of us. The light will prevail. Have faith in the Force, young one.”

Skywalker wrinkles his nose. “Don’t call me that.” He sits next to Kenobi and swipes his caf. Cody nudges his own cup toward Kenobi in response. “I’m a knight now. How come Master Jinn is still—” Skywalker makes a motion with his hand that doesn’t mean anything to Rex but Kenobi nods as if it makes sense to him.

“He will always be your teacher. We spend our lives learning.”

“Ugh.” Skywalker groans and aims a light-hearted kick at Kenobi’s shins. Kenobi lets the hit land.

“How’s your prosthetic?” Kenobi asks.

“It’s mechanical, not organic so it isn’t your business.”

“And the connection site?” Kenobi asks, unfazed by the outburst. “Does it still hurt?”

Skywalker’s expression can only be described as sullen. “Sometimes.”

“Come to the med-bay with me so I can look at it.”

“Do I get a lollipop?”

Kenobi laughs as he ushers Skywalker toward the door. “Of course.”

Once they’re gone and the door closes behind them, Rex begins counting. Once he reaches five-hundred and one, he looks over at Cody. “The Jedi aren’t perfect.”

It’s akin to blasphemy.

If he said it on Kamino, he would be decommissioned.

Cody isn’t a longneck, but he might punch Rex or assign him punishment work.

“They aren’t,” Cody says slowly, as if he’s testing the words. “We were made for them. They need us.”

“Yeah, for the war.” Rex went through training. He’s heard it all before.

Cody shakes his head. “They need us,” he repeats.

And then he sits in brooding silence until Rex gives up and leaves.

#

Rex is back on The Resolute when he receives permission to view the video of Kenobi fighting Dooku. Even though time is precious, he watches the entire thing at normal speed.

Rex thinks he could watch Skywalker fight every day and still be awed by it. Watching Kenobi is something different. He likened himself to a mountain, steady and sure, and Rex understands the comparison. He defends and deflects and blocks and he doesn’t tire. He isn’t tricked by fancy moves or shaken by powerful strikes.

He withstands.

Rex enlists the help of Fives and Echo to download the video so the Jedi can’t revoke his access. And then he breaks it into pieces and begins to watch it in slow motion. Kenobi was right, this is Master Dooku, not Count Dooku, but there are still things to be learned, and Rex will learn them.

Fizz admits he and Baar’ur had a rocky start, but there is no one he trusts more than his fellow medic. They understand each other. War is hell, too many hurt and not enough hands or supplies to hold them together.

Baar’ur understands. He fights as hard as any of them to keep the vode living, and he says the Remembrances for the ones they can’t save, and, on the very bad nights, he adds a shot of liquor to his caf.

When he isn’t with his squad, bringing back survivors or on-shift, he’s in his lab. What had first appeared to be a special privilege given to a Jedi medic has turned out to be something more than Fizz ever could have imagined.
