Fizz is one of the few read into Baar’ur’s side mission. Of the 212th, only Commander Cody also knows. And the only other person Fizz has been told he can discuss this with is General Koon, the one who assisted Baar’ur in gaining the space and equipment he needed.

The secrecy is so no one can tell Baar’ur to stop. It’s also because Baar’ur doesn’t want to get anyone’s hopes up. He told Fizz, when Fizz was first read in, that hope can inspire, but it also can kill.

Fizz knows how to keep a secret, and he keeps this one.

Whenever they have spare time, they spend it in the labs, studying blood samples and console readouts and trying to determine the source of the double-aging and how to reverse it.

Baar’ur cares. Not only about the war but about the vode. He learns their names and their favorite foods and where they want to visit once the war is over. He keeps them alive now and he researches how to keep them alive after the war.

It isn’t that the other Jedi don’t care but they’re cold. Fizz thinks it’s to do with their rules about attachment. Baar’ur is warmth. He is fire, starting at the top of his head and spreading all the way down.

Fizz doesn’t care about lightsabers. All anyone could talk about after Baar’ur’s spar with Skywalker was about how none of them knew. And then some footage circulated of a shiny Baar’ur fighting Master Dooku. Fizz still doesn’t care. Baar’ur can fight, of course he can fight, he’s Mandalorian. But he can also heal, and Fizz cares more about that than anything else.

And that’s the other thing. Baar’ur speaks Mando’a. And he wears beskar. Cody frowns at him sometimes, as if he’s trying to figure out why Baar’ur looks bigger sometimes and smaller at others. Fizz figured it out first, but he hasn’t told anyone.

Baar’ur has armor.

It isn’t a full set like the vode. And it isn’t mass-produced, either. He has a few pieces of beskar’gam. Fizz wants to know why. And how. And when. He hasn’t asked. Baar’ur wears his armor under his robes. A Mandalorian in Jedi robes.

Is he trying to fool himself?

“Fuck, fuck, fuck!”

Fizz is pulled out of his thoughts at the cursing on his comm. He whirls around the med-tent as if expecting a deluge of vode to pour in.

Nothing.

“Emergency Protocol 2.1.12,” a new, measured voice says. It’s Boil. “Code: CC-2224. Authorization: CT-2313.”

Fizz feels a rock lodge itself in his stomach. He sits behind the console in the med-tent. The screen flickers and then he sees the barren rock and scraggly scrub that marks this Manda-forsaken planet.

Emergency Protocol 2.1.12 activates the camera and recorder on a trooper’s helmet and provides the feed to command and medical. It’s done in extreme cases, and Fizz doesn’t want to know why it’s Commander Cody’s helmet being activated.

“Did I hear what I thought I heard?” Baar’ur hurries over. He looks over Fizz’s shoulder and swears in a combination of Basic and Mando’a as if one language isn’t enough.

Commander Cody’s helmet is not on Commander Cody’s head. Fizz knows this, because the helmet is now pointing at Commander Cody, who is slumped against a tent pole, restrained even though the bit of metal piping through his stomach would keep him from moving.

He’s surrounded by droids who titter over their good fortune.

“Boil has eyes on him,” Fizz says.

Baar’ur activates his comm. “Boil, this is Kenobi. Send me your coordinates and hold your position until I’m there.”

“Sir—” Boil begins.

“That’s an order,” Baar’ur says. He looks at Fizz. “Be ready. I’m bringing him home.”

“I know, sir,” Fizz says.

#

Fizz doesn’t believe in the Force the way the Jedi do. He knows they can do things with it, but it’s invisible to him. Fizz believes in Baar’ur, though. He sits by the console and watches the droids taunt Commander Cody. Baar’ur will rescue him. Will bring him here and Fizz will save him.

And then Boil and the rest of vode with him will blow those droids back to the scrapyard they came from.

It feels like an interminable wait until the helmet picks up on movement.

Baar’ur jumps down into the droids’ camp. “Hello, there,” he greets. He holds his hands up as if droids care about gestures of peace. Fizz wonders if he’s about to witness the death of a Jedi. “I’m here for my commander. Would you mind handing him over?”

“He is our hostage,” one of the droids says.

“He won’t be if he bleeds out,” Baar’ur says. “Will you let me treat him at least?”

“If we have you, we don’t need him,” the droid says.

“We can do this peacefully,” Baar’ur says as if it’s possible to negotiate with fucking droids. “Or, I can fight you.”

The droids chitter as if they’re amused. The spokesdroid speaks again. “Those colors mean you’re a medic.”

The video is clear enough for Fizz to see the way Baar’ur draws in on himself, preparing to fight. The tension in his body is belied by the easy tone of his voice. “Yes, I am a medic. And you’re standing between me and my patient.” Baar’ur’s smile is too sharp to be friendly. “Commander, you have beskar in your veins. You are the foundation that holds strong.”

Commander Cody blinks blearily.

“Focus, Commander Cody,” Baar’ur says. “You have beskar in your veins. You are the foundation that holds strong.”

Fizz can barely make out the shape of Commander Cody’s mouth as he moves around the syllables of beskar. And then Baar’ur throws out his hands, and the camp flies backwards. Droids, tents, charging stations, cannons, they’re thrown backward with the strongest show of the Force that Fizz has ever seen Baar’ur use.

Tent poles are ripped from the ground, maps scatter, and droids beep in alarm as they go head over foot.

Commander Cody doesn’t budge.

Fizz releases a breath he didn’t know he was holding. And then he leans closer to the screen as the droids regain their footing. Baar’ur charges forward, and he ignites his saber, as he stands over Commander Cody.

“Now, Boil!”

Boil and the vode with him fire on the droids. The droids fire back. And in the center, Baar’ur deflects any stray blasterfire away from Commander Cody. Fizz hadn’t been impressed by the spar with Skywalker or the one against Dooku. But this. This holds Fizz’s attention.

The droids are smarter than Fizz wants them to be. Most of them return fire at Boil and his men, but a few aim at Baar’ur and Commander Cody as if they don’t care about hostages anymore, only dealing the most damage to the GAR as they can.

None of the shots make it through. Baar’ur’s lightsaber is a blur of motion, quick, sweeping arcs which deflect the blasterfire away from himself and Cody even as the droids do their best to slip a shot through his guard.

Five minutes stretch into ten, into thirty and then sixty. Fizz is glued to his chair as a battle rages between his vode and the clankers. And in the center, holding strong, is Baar’ur.

Finally, it ends. Fizz sees Boil and the others fan out to make sure the area is clear. But Fizz is certain it is, because Baar’ur powers down his saber and kneels at Commander Cody’s side. He wouldn’t do that if the Force told him there’s still danger nearby.

There are no witnesses to Baar’ur and Commander Cody except for the helmet. Fizz feels as though he’s intruding on a private moment as Baar’ur calls Commander Cody’s helmet to where they are, but he doesn’t turn off the transmission. There is protocol to follow.

“Commander, stay with me,” Baar’ur says.

Commander Cody’s skin is unnaturally pale from blood loss. His gaze lands on Baar’ur and then slides away. The rock in Fizz’s stomach grows heavier. He knows these signs. And he knows how far Baar’ur is from camp.

“Stay with me,” Baar’ur repeats, but his voice isn’t firm anymore. He almost sounds like he’s pleading.

“That an order, sir?” Commander Cody slurs.

“That’s right,” Baar’ur says. He runs his hands from Commander Cody’s head to his toes, doing the Force scan that Jedi healers can do. “It’s an order. And I’m the Chief Healer of the Galactic Army of the Republic. Do you know what that means?”

Commander Cody mumbles something unintelligible.

“I outrank everyone,” Baar’ur answers. “That includes you. So, you’re going to stay with me. I’m going to bring you home.”

“Yes, sir,” Commander Cody says.

Fizz has a hard time swallowing. His throat feels too thick. He turns away from his screen. When he processes the video from Commander Cody’s helmet, he’ll cut the last few minutes. There is protocol, but protocol can go fuck itself.

#

Commander Cody becomes a grumpy, semi-permanent resident of med-bay. And, because he doesn’t want Baar’ur to think he’s grumpy with him, Commander Cody saves all his asshole behavior for Fizz.

Fortunately, medics go through tougher training than even the CCs. Commander Cody can be an asshole, but Fizz can dish it right back.

Currently, Fizz is perched in view of Commander Cody but out of Baar’ur’s line of vision. He watches, eyebrows raised in judgement, as Commander Cody sifts through the jar of lollipops until he finds the one he wants.

When Baar’ur brought this practice to the med-bay, Fizz understood. The burst of sugar helps with recovery, whether it’s physical recovery or getting over the jitters of being in med-bay. And then Baar’ur shook his head and said the lollipops were for spiritual healing.

Which is bantha shit. Fizz told him that then, and he still believes it now.

The fact that Baar’ur and Commander Cody now have a daily ritual of lollipop selection is nausea inducing.

Fizz isn’t paid enough for this shit.

#

The war is…going. No one is certain whether they’re winning or not. They’re on their way to rendezvous with the 501st and have a bit of downtime. If recovering from one campaign and preparing for the next can be considered downtime.

Fizz’s med-bay is nearly empty which isn’t as good as completely empty but is better than full. He skims the latest report Chin-up from the 104th submitted to the medic group chat. They found a plant that can be pressed for a salve which shares a lot of properties with bacta. It’s a natural and much less expensive way to treat wounds. There will be on-ship cultivation centers soon as well as planets dedicated to growing it for the GAR.

Alderaan and Naboo have both volunteered land and labor to grow the plant. It’s a reminder that they have allies.

Fizz flips to the next report.

“Fizz?” Baar’ur sticks his head out of his labs. His voice is even, perfectly controlled, which means he’s hiding some kind of reaction. “Could I trouble you for a moment?”

“Trix, the med-bay is yours,” Fizz says, delegating, before he joins Baar’ur in his labs.

As soon as the doors close, Baar’ur ushers Fizz toward the console. “I found something.”

Fizz scans the information. “You figured out how to reverse the advanced aging.”

“Yes, yes,” Baar’ur says, almost dismissive.

Rather than growing offended, Fizz worries. “What else did you find?” Because if Baar’ur isn’t throwing a party over reversing the advanced aging, he must have found something bad.

“We’ve talked about how even-keeled the vode are,” Baar’ur says. “How it was odd.”

“Yes.”

“Almost like you’re taking mood stabilizers. But you’re not. Not consciously, at least.”

“What?” Fizz looks back at the console.

Baar’ur taps a few keys and new information pops up. Chips. There are chips inside the vode’s heads. He heard the longnecks talk about behavior modification and insurance, but he didn’t understand. Now he does. From Baar’ur’s research, these chips release hormones and neurotransmitters to regulate the vode’s behavior and their emotions.

No, more than that. Fizz knows his anatomy and physiology. It’s how he got his name after all. Phys looked odd so he chose Fizz. Neurophysiology is its own beast, but Fizz was bred to be the best. He knows. He knows.

Hormones, neurotransmitters, they affect thought, memory, emotion, touch, motor skills, vision, breathing, temperature, hunger, the whole fucking body. The vode were cloned, they were altered, and then they were grown, and they were trained. Horrifying but it happened.

The thought of these chips which continue to alter and control them? No. They’re supposed to be their own people now.

“Fizz!” Baar’ur’s voice is sharp and it cuts through Fizz’s panic. “We discovered the chips. We’re going to get them out.”

“Are we?” Fizz asks. Someone put them there. The longnecks? Obviously, they put them there but on whose orders?

“We are going to gather all the medics and show them how to reverse the rapid aging. And, quietly, we’re going to tell them about the chips. Both procedures will be done at the same time. But this doesn’t go beyond the medics. And we may limit the number of medics who know.”

“Sir?” Wouldn’t having more hands on this be better?

Baar’ur takes a deep breath. He looks troubled as he glances at the console again. “We still don’t know who was behind creating you and the vode. And now there are control chips? Something is very, very wrong here. Maybe, it’s the evil of slavery and nonconsensual body modification I’m feeling. But maybe, it’s something else. If someone is controlling you and your brothers for their own reasons, we don’t want to tip our hand.”

Fizz nods. “We keep it quiet, but we take the chips out.”

“Taking them out was never in question,” Baar’ur says.

“If I may make a suggestion? Read Commander Cody into this.” Fizz presses on even as Baar’ur doesn’t look persuaded. “He deserves to know, and he’ll be able to help us coordinate. This will be difficult to pull off.”

Baar’ur shakes his head. “At best, I’d be asking him to lie to his commanding officer. At worst, I’d be asking him to commit treason.”

“It’s his choice to make,” Fizz says.

Baar’ur blanches, no doubt thinking of how many choices the vode haven’t been able to make. How many these chips are preventing them from making. “Alright. Tomorrow evening. Have him meet us in here.”

#

Baar’ur looks like shit. His hair is limp and greasy like it hasn’t been washed days. There are dark circles under his eyes like he isn’t sleeping either. He paces the lab like a caged animal, just waiting until it can spring free.

If Fizz looks in a mirror, he’d probably see that he doesn’t look like a holostar either.

Commander Cody clears his throat. “Before we begin, I would like to clear something up. General Jinn is not my commanding officer. As of Zygerria, I outrank him.”

And wasn’t that hell in a fucking handbasket. Is it bad that Fizz is glad Commander Cody can override General Jinn’s orders? Looking over at Baar’ur, Fizz decides he’s at least in good company. He remembers Baar’ur’s fury that Skywalker, a former slave, was being forced undercover as a slave master.

Fizz wishes Baar’ur saved some of that fury for his own behalf. Baar’ur hasn’t talked about his own experience on the mission. As far as Fizz knows, Rex hasn’t either. And that’s telling in itself.

“Was the Council going to tell us?” Baar’ur asks.

Commander Cody offers a small shrug. “When it became relevant, I assume.”

Baar’ur sighs. “Congratulations, Commander. And, apologies. It is a large responsibility, but I can think of no one better.”

“What is it that you brought me here for?” Commander Cody asks.

“We can reverse the accelerated aging,” Baar’ur answers. “We plan to gather the medics of the other battalions and share our findings and begin the process as soon as possible.”

“We may have to do it in groups but yes.” Commander Cody looks at Baar’ur and then Fizz. “And the bad thing you have to tell me?”

“In the process of my research—”

Fizz cuts Baar’ur off. “There are chips in our heads.”

Commander Cody’s face goes terrifying blank. “What?”

Baar’ur takes over again. “From what I can tell, they release hormones or neurotransmitters in order to regulate; well, a hell of a lot. Emotions and behavior, primarily. The Kaminoans mentioned something about curbing aggression, but we never looked deeply into it. I think this is what they were referring to.”

“Chips,” Commander Cody says. He rubs his forehead and then drops his hand to his side. “Are they dangerous?”

“Yes,” Fizz answers but Commander Cody is looking at Baar’ur, not him.

“We use hormone treatments and neurotransmitters as part of healing,” Baar’ur says. “Serotonin is a neurotransmitter. But these chips—we don’t know who placed them in your heads, we don’t know how they control what is administered and in what doses. In my professional opinion, yes, they are dangerous.”

“Can you remove them without arousing suspicion?”

Of course, Commander Cody jumps to this question. He listens as Baar’ur gives the same answer he gave Fizz last night. The two of them, Commander Cody and Baar’ur, they understand each other.

“Secrecy is paramount,” Commander Cody says. “I want the list of medics you plan to meet with. We review and clear them together. I also want reports on when the procedures begin and their progress until they’re completed.”

“You’ll have them,” Baar’ur promises. He seems to dither for a moment before he reaches out to rest his hand on Commander Cody’s shoulder.

Commander Cody’s eyes close and he leans into the touch.

The Dooku situation is fucked, and Rex knows a thing or two about fucked up situations.

Dooku trained General Jinn. And General Jinn trained Skywalker which makes them a fucked-up family. Lineage. Whatever.

Again, Rex knows a thing or two about fucked up families. His father was Jango fucking Fett and even though he’ll have over a million brothers when this damned war is finally over, it won’t be enough because he should have twice that.

He’s heard about Geonosis, about how General Jinn tracked the Prime from Coruscant to Kamino and then to Geonosis where he was captured and lightly tortured and taunted by Dooku for a bit. And then Skywalker and Senator Amidala showed up, and they were all slated for execution. War broke out, Skywalker battled Dooku and lost his arm, General Jinn was there and couldn’t deliver the killing blow.

Dooku escaped.

And now.

And now, they have him in their sights.

Well, Rex and Torrent do.

The 212th is on the main assault, and the 501st is executing a pincer movement to cut off the enemy and trap them between them. Rex is leading Torrent on a side mission, because they heard there’s a Seppie base where they’ve kept captured vode. Kenobi is with them, because if there are vode here, they’re in rough shape.

Cody threatened Rex before he entrusted Kenobi with Torrent. It’s been three days, and Rex has finally remembered how to breathe normally so of course Fives comes back to report that not only is there a Seppie base, but the Count himself is currently in residence.

“I have an idea,” Kenobi says.

“No.”

Kenobi pouts as if that expression will sway Rex at all. “You haven’t even heard it, yet.”

“Cody briefed me before assigning you to Torrent,” Rex says.

Now, Kenobi sniffs, offended. “I’m loaned to Torrent. There’s a difference.”

Rex sighs. “What’s your idea?” They don’t have the time for Kenobi to wax poetic about the 212th and how much he loves his battalion or the 212th’s grumpy asshole of a commander.

“There are men, good men, in there who need to be freed, but if Dooku notices an escape attempt, he’ll kill them. We need a distraction.”

Fives perks up, the fucking maniac. “Explosives?”

“A duel,” Kenobi says.

Everyone swings their attention to Rex as if waiting for him to shut Kenobi down now that he knows what the plan is. Cody did warn Rex to reflexively say no to any suggestion Kenobi made outside of healing matters. He also warned Rex about what would happen to Rex’s dick, balls, and head if anything happened to Kenobi. Specifically, those things would no longer be attached to the rest of his body.

But…Rex has seen the footage from Kenobi’s first duel with Dooku. He’s studied it more than is probably healthy.

“He isn’t a Jedi anymore,” Rex says, because someone has to be the voice of reason. If it’s him, then they’re fucked.

“And I’m not a padawan. I can do this.” Kenobi’s conviction is evident in his voice and in the set of his shoulders. “I can get you the time you need to evacuate our men.”

“And will you be able to safely disengage once we’re clear?” Rex asks.

“Yes.”

“Alright,” Rex says. “This is the plan.”

#

Rex shadows Kenobi. He follows the baar’ur through the maze-like halls of the base. He stays out of sight as Kenobi saunters into Dooku’s throne room. An actual fucking throne room. What a fucking dramatic piece of shit.

Count Dooku smirks as he turns to greet Kenobi. “Does Qui-Gon know you’re here, little one?”

Kenobi scoffs which is good because it saves Rex from having to do it and give away his position. “I’m not a child anymore, Count. And Qui-Gon’s not in charge of me. Perk of being a medic. I’m outside the chain of command.”

“Medic?” Dooku’s lips curl up as if he’s caught Kenobi doing something wrong. “Not a healer? Why, Obi-Wan, have you changed allegiances?”

Kenobi unclips his saber. “Are we doing this or not?”

“So eager to die. I know my padawan and my grandpadawan are on the planet. Why did they send you instead of them?”

“It didn’t go so well for them the last time they faced you,” Kenobi answers.

“You lost last time we fought,” Dooku says.

“I was fifteen. I’ve learned a lot since then.”

“So have I.” Dooku ignites his saber and the red blade glows ominously in the room.

Dooku throws himself at Kenobi. Even with Rex’s enhancements the movement is almost too fast for him to follow. Before he can worry Kenobi won’t react in time, the two sabers clash in a loud grind.

Kenobi spins away from the Sith, and holds his saber out in front of him, prepared for the next attack.

“You have learned nothing,” Dooku says and then attacks once more.

#

Being a Sith has undoubtedly make Dooku stronger but, Rex notes, it makes him more impatient as well. Rex had been impressed by how long Dooku and Kenobi sparred in the Temple video. He isn’t sure this fight will go that long. Dooku doesn’t have the temperament for it anymore.

Already, he’s thrown various objects at Kenobi using the Force, and he’s even thrown some Force lightning in the Sith-equivalent of a temper tantrum. Kenobi has weathered each challenge, his saber creating a dome of safety that nothing can pierce; not Dooku’s saber, not flying chairs, and not even creepy electricity.

“You can’t hold out forever,” Dooku says.

“You’d sound more convincing if you weren’t out of breath,” Kenobi says, as steady now as he had been at the start of the fight.

“I am a Makashi master! I am an expert in dueling other lightsaber wielders. You can’t expect to win.”

“Who ever said I wanted to win?” Kenobi’s smile is bright and a touch unhinged. “How long have we been dueling, Count? At least an hour, I’d wager.”

“You—” The Count’s face twists in rage. “You were a diversion.”

“A good one.”

“No matter. You will be a sacrifice. Will the Jedi think it’s a worthy trade? One of their own for a handful of clones?”

Dooku redoubles his efforts. Rex tracks the two Force users as they move about the room. He can tell Kenobi is tiring. There is something to be said for the sheer, brute force Dooku commands, and as good as Kenobi is, he can’t hold up against the assault forever.

Fives checks in to tell Rex they’ve extracted all their people, and they’ve rigged the base to explode when they’re ready. Rex wishes he had a good way to signal to Kenobi that they’re clear to disengage but since Kenobi doesn’t know Rex is here…

It’d be a good time for the Force to do its thing and help communicate.

“Why won’t you give up?” Dooku demands as he batters at Kenobi’s guard, thrust after thrust, each one stronger than the last. “You cannot defeat me!”

Dooku swings down and Kenobi drops his fucking lightsaber and traps Dooku’s saber between his arms.

“I know I can’t,” Kenobi says.

And that’s when Rex realizes Kenobi’s positioned them so that Rex has a clear shot at Dooku’s back. While Dooku’s saber is pinned and his entire attention is on Kenobi. Fucking Force fucking shit.

Rex shoots. Three shots to be safe. Head. Chest. Head again.

Dooku falls to the ground. His saber powers down and the hilt rolls across the floor. Kenobi kneels down and places two fingers against Dooku’s pulse. He looks over at Rex. His face is shiny with sweat. There are holes in his sleeves where Dooku’s saber burned through the fabric and then was stopped by—by beskar.

“You’re full of surprises,” Rex says.

“Indeed.” Kenobi grimaces and looks up at Rex. “I’m afraid I have another. I’m not entirely certain I can stand on my own. Holding a Sith at bay is more difficult than I anticipated.”

Rex rolls his eyes, but he clips Dooku’s saber to his belt and then helps Kenobi to his feet. Kenobi sways alarmingly, and Rex drapes one of Kenobi’s arms over Rex’s shoulders and then he wraps his own arm around Kenobi’s waist.

Together, they stagger out of the base.

Once they’re clear of it, Rex gives Fives the go-ahead. He shuffles around so he and Kenobi can watch the base collapse in on itself.

“Dooku’s dead,” Rex says. He took the shot himself. He saw Kenobi check and now there’s the explosion. It still doesn’t feel real.

Kenobi pats Rex’s cuirass. “I’m afraid you won’t escape promotion this time, Captain.”

“Oh, fuck,” Rex says.

#

Rex leads Torrent to where the 212th and 501st are camped out after their success on the battlefield. They crest the hill with their rescued vode and cheers erupt in response. Rex is glad to smile and accept a few back slaps and then leave the vode to their reunion and celebrating. He slips through the crowd with Kenobi, and they take refuge in the Command Tent.

It’s only a partial refuge, because General Jinn, Skywalker, and Cody are all there.

“Sirs,” Rex greets, because he can be a professional when he tries. He unclips Dooku’s saber and places it on the table. “Primary mission to retrieve our POWs was a success. Secondary mission to eliminate a major threat was also a success.”

General Jinn stares at the lightsaber hilt as if it’s speaking to him. Hell, for all Rex knows, it could be.

“General Dooku is dead?” Cody confirms.

“Yes,” Kenobi answers. He attempts to rally and stand on his own, but he ends up against Rex’s side again after only a moment. “Captain Rex showed initiative and bravery in the field. Additionally, he was responsible for eliminating a Sith and Separatist general. It is my opinion that he should be acknowledged and rewarded for the actions he took today.”

Rex glares at the top of Kenobi’s head, embarrassed and pleased and unsure how to react.

“He put you in danger,” Cody says flatly. Rex has a pretty good idea of how Cody wants to “reward” him for his actions today.

“I put me in danger,” Kenobi says. “Captain Rex got me out of it. Commander, it’s been a trying day. Could I trouble you to help me to my bunk?”

“Of course,” Cody says, far too solicitous. “Fizz has a bed already reserved for you.”

Kenobi groans but he goes easily enough, shifting from Rex’s side to Cody’s once Cody is in reach. “I’m voluntarily resting. Do you have to push for the med-tent as well? Fizz will scold me.”

“Yes. And once you’re more awake, I will as well.” Cody’s expression softens minutely as he brushes Kenobi’s hair out of his face. And then he glances up and catches Rex’s eyes, and his expression hardens again.

Rex sighs. Bastard’s going to double-promote him or something in retribution.

“You rescued our vode, and you took out a Separatist general,” Cody says. “I’m proud of you.”

Fuck you, Rex mouths so that General Jinn and Skywalker won’t hear.

Cody, the bastard, just laughs and then guides Kenobi out of the tent.

Rex turns back to the generals. “Would you like a full report?”

Cody is there, in the Senate Chambers, when the Jedi Council confronts Chancellor Palpatine. It didn’t make sense, even as the evidence piled up. Security leaks that came from high up. A lack of supplies or back-up at crucial moments. Senator Amidala’s fears, grave enough that she approached Baar’ur. General Skywalker’s slow descent into something dark.

Except, it did make sense. Each piece of evidence pointed to an obvious conclusion but not one that any of them wanted to believe.

The Jedi, their generals, they face Chancellor Palpatine, the man behind both armies, the man behind the war, the Sith who has played the galaxy like puppets for his entertainment.

Cody bears witness as General Windu accuses the Chancellor of crimes against the Republic. Of treason.

Cody sees the delight on the Sith’s face, and he doesn’t understand. Why create this war? Why orchestrate so much destruction? He already had power. What is there to be gained by ruling over the smoldering ashes of a galaxy?

“You fools,” Chancellor Palpatine says, and his voice is a low hiss. Before Cody’s very eyes, he ages, his face developing deep set wrinkles, his shoulders hunching. He becomes something twisted or maybe, they finally see him for what he’s been all along. “Blinded by your precious light.”

“We believe in the Force,” General Windu says. “Through the light, we gain clarity and through unity, we gain strength. We will stand against the darkness, and we will prevail.”

“You will fall, and I will grow my new galaxy from your corpses.”

Charming, Cody thinks. Like the vode around him, he has his blaster out, and is prepared to fire at the order from any of their generals. He isn’t sure how effective blasters will be against a Sith master, but he was made for the Jedi, and the Jedi need him now.

Palpatine, no Sidious, looks through the force assembled to face him, and his gaze hones in on Cody. He smiles, a sickly impression of an actual smile. “You weren’t made for the Jedi, CC-2224. You were made for me.”

Once, Baar’ur told Cody he has beskar in his veins. Cody allows that belief to fill him. He stands taller, meets Sidious’s gaze evenly, his helmet and all its sensors trained on the Sith. “My name is Cody.”

Sidious’s smile twists into something uglier. “Apologies, Commander Cody. I suppose I can indulge you in your last moments.”

Cody’s gaze is on Sidious, but he can see his vode respond in his peripherals. Rex has his blaster trained on Sidious with his finger already on the trigger, prepared to fire. Somewhere in the room is Baar’ur himself, and he brushes his mind against Cody’s, a reminder Cody isn’t alone.

“Commander, execute Order 66,” Sidious says.

Cody doesn’t react.

It clearly isn’t what Sidious expects, because the Sith hisses again. He looks around the assembled vode. “Did you hear me? Execute Order 66!”

“We don’t take orders from Sith,” Cody says.

“What did you do?” Sidious turns, his gaze searching the crowd. “What did you do to my clones?” His gaze lands on someone, and Cody doesn’t need to feel the sinking sensation in his stomach to know which Jedi Sidious has singled out. “You.”

“They weren’t only behavior modifiers,” Baar’ur says. There’s muted horror in his words, as if he’s trying not to think through the implications.

Cody doesn’t have much success holding his thoughts at bay. The chips. Sidious’s order. He isn’t sure what Order 66 was. He doesn’t want to know. All he can feel is relied that the control chips are gone.

“No matter,” Sidious says, recovering. “You are weak.” He throws out his hands and lightning shoots out.

Baar’ur leaps in front of the lightning, and he meets the strike with his saber. It’s enough to spur everyone else into action. Cody, Rex, and the ten best men from each of their battalions are here along with four high generals, two regular generals, and Baar’ur.

It should be overkill, but Sidious swats them aside like they’re nothing. Blaster bolts are deflected into the walls. Lightsaber attacks are pushed back. Sidious holds them off with one hand and attacks with the other.

Cody holsters his blaster a few minutes into the fighting. It’s more likely that Sidious will guide one of Cody’s shots into a vod or a Jedi than one of them will hit the Sith. With his blaster not an option, Cody signals to his vode. They follow his lead and holster their weapons.

And then, at his signal, they charge.

Cody has spent the past three years fighting alongside Jedi. He’s learned a thing or two. They’re powerful. They can do things beyond the ability of a normal sentient. It takes a lot to tire them out. It takes even more to overwhelm them.

But it’s possible.

Cody and nineteen of his vode rush Sidious. Cody doesn’t expect them all to reach him. He hopes at least one of them will.

Sidious raises his hands and lightning crackles at his fingertips. Cody doesn’t falter. He draws a blade and throws it, even as he reaches for another.

Lightning pours out of Sidious’s hands. Cody flinches and it takes him a moment to realize he isn’t hurt. The lightning is channeled upward, a pillar of blue energy that sparks and beats against invisible walls.

Cody throws another knife. This one hits. Sidious howls, at Cody’s hit or maybe Rex’s or maybe at the way his lightning is contained, directed away from his enemies by Baar’ur.

Two more strides and Cody will jam a knife into Sidious’s throat.

Without using his hands, Sidious throws Cody and his vode backward. They fly, boots over bucket, tumbling through the air. He’s caught before he slams into the wall or the ground. He’s lowered gently and looks around to see Plo Koon and some of the other Jedi cushioning his and his vode’s fall.

Sidious, lightning still pouring from his hands, cackles as he flings Rex through the air again. “This is the power of the darkside.”

And Cody can see it. It takes all of Baar’ur’s considerable strength to hold the lightning at bay. It takes four Jedi to keep the vode from shattering against the walls. Sidious doesn’t even look tired.

“The darkside is bantha shit,” Cody says, getting to his feet.

Sidious hisses and tosses him again.

“Fuck you,” Rex says, his turn to throw out a jab as he realizes what Cody is doing.

Distraction.

Overwhelm him.

Because it does take Baar’ur to counter the Force lightning. And it does take twenty vode and four generals to keep Sidious’s telekinesis busy.

But that still leaves two Jedi not accounted for.

General Skywalker leads a frontal assault while General Windu approaches from behind. Sidious is too busy swatting vode as they stand up to him to notice. Cody’s getting to his feet for the fourth time, slower than the third, as General Windu’s purple blade punctures Sidious’s chest.

General Skywalker drives his blade through the Sith next.

“No!” Sidious shouts, somehow still clinging to life. “No!”

His screams echo through the chamber, even after General Windu cuts off his head. The air in the chamber constricts, like someone drawing breath, and then it exhales, and it throws everyone in the room backward.

Cody finally hits the wall, no Jedi available to help this time. His armor takes the brunt of it, but he groans as he, once again, finds his feet. He staggers over to Waxer and offers him his hand. Waxer grips it, and Cody helps pull him to his feet.

Waxer goes to help Boil, and Cody offers his hand to General Koon.

There’s a black mark on the ground where Sidious’s robes are bunched in a pile. There’s no body.

Something isn’t right. Cody scans the room. Rex, Waxer, Boil, Koon, Windu, Skywalker—

His gaze falls to the one figure still on the floor.

Baar’ur.

He rushes to Baar’ur’s side. There’s blood trickling from the corner of his mouth. His breathing is shallow, labored, and it stutters like when the power shorts out.

“We’ll get him to the Halls of Healing,” General Windu promises.

Rex eases Cody back so General Windu and General Skywalker can lift Baar’ur in the air. Cody has seen the power of the Jedi. He has seen miracles.

He looks at the black spot on the floor and hopes they haven’t used all their miracles up.

#

Cody sits, vigilant, at Baar’ur’s side.

Baar’ur is improving, because Cody’s allowed in the room. He used to watch from the outside, haunting the visitor’s room, lurking by the window as the healers did their jobs. But now Cody has a chair. He doesn’t leave the room except to use the fresher. His vode bring him food.

The war is over and there is nowhere else he needs to be.

“Can I help?” Cody asks, on the second day of his vigil.

Healer Che is worn down, but she isn’t exhausted anymore. Cody knows better than to bother a medic in the midst of a crisis. But the crisis is over, because the healers don’t rotate in shifts, one of them always at Baar’ur’s side, using their healing powers.

Cody watched them rotate, each taking turns at Baar’ur’s side, taking turns supporting each other, taking turns resting so they could do it again. Cody didn’t speak up then, but he speaks up now.

“Baar’ur says the Force is in all things,” Cody explains and he feels foolish, a bit like a shiny who makes the mistake of talking to a superior officer, but this is Baar’ur. He can weather a bit of humiliation. “If the Force is in me, you can use it.”

“Oh,” Healer Che says, and Cody can feel when she understands what he’s trying to ask. “It’s not like that. But there is something. Stay here.”

Cody raises his eyebrows, but he doesn’t speak. Where else has he been since he was allowed entry?

Healer Che returns with a rock. It’s a glowing rock, but it’s still a rock. Cody isn’t sure how this is supposed to help, but she places it on the round table at Cody’s left.

“This is a healing crystal,” Healer Che says. “It can pass through thoughts, emotions, maybe even faint memories. Obi-Wan has a long fight ahead of him.” She runs her hand through Obi-Wan’s hair, and there’s a wealth of fondness in the touch. “You can help.”

Cody looks at the rock. Crystal. He doesn’t completely understand Jedi and their ways. But if Baar’ur is stuck in his own mind while he heals, if he’s aware but trapped. Cody swallows back his instinctual fear at the thought of being trapped anywhere, let alone his own mind.

“Clear your mind,” Healer Che counsels. “Only touch the crystal if you can pass on positive emotions.”

“Yes, ma’am,” Cody promises.

Cody closes his eyes. He thinks about Baar’ur standing in a med-tent, chaos around him. That was his frontline. While Cody learned to filter out distractions as clankers fired on them, Baar’ur filtered out cries of pain and pleas for help until he could identify where he was needed most.

Safety.

Comfort.

Hope.

Cody thinks of all these things and curls his fingers around the crystal.

#

Rex comes by with a tray of food. Cody explains the crystal to him, and Rex looks at it curiously, before he shrugs and sits down on the other side of the table. He touches the crystal while Cody eats.

Fizz comes by, and he complains about Jedi and their magic and invisible healing, but he wraps both hands around the crystal and stays for over an hour.

The Baar’ur squad comes, and they touch the crystal together. Officers and shinies from every battalion pass through at least once. Senator Organa makes an appearance. Senator Amidala does as well.

There are waves of Jedi, generals and commanders and even the little ones, and Cody has to make a roster that he posts outside the door in order to put some kind of order into this system.

There is always someone touching the crystal.

Cody touches it more than most. He isn’t afraid of running out of memories.

Baar’ur standing over him, a wall between him and the clankers after he was captured.

Baar’ur’s fury when he found the chips, because how dare anyone take the vode’s ability to choose away from them.

Baar’ur’s smile when Cody handed him a cup of caf, sweetened exactly how he liked it.

Baar’ur’s offer to share a cup when it was the last one and both of them were too tired to brew another pot.

There is peace. There is hope. There is comfort and gratitude and humor.

And beneath it all, there is love.

#

Baar’ur wakes up when Cody is on watch. He blinks his eyes open and then sits up as if he hasn’t been in a healing trance for the better part of a month. Healer Che rushes in, two healers on her heels, but Baar’ur doesn’t notice them.

He smiles at Cody, and his eyes crinkle at the corners. “I had the most wonderful dreams,” he says.

Cody clasps Baar’ur’s hand in his. “I’m glad.”

#

Baar’ur has just as many visitors now as he did when he was in his trance. The only difference is that he grows tired easily, and none of the visitors are allowed to stay long.

None of them, except Cody.

During the day, he sleeps, he eats, he spends time with his vode, and he trains whenever one of them drags him into the salles. But at night, he takes his place at Baar’ur’s side.

Baar’ur always reaches out, and Cody accepts the offer and holds his hand. Sometimes, Baar’ur talks until his words become mumbles and then he falls asleep. Sometimes, it’s Cody who talks. And sometimes they sit, comfortable in their silence.

#

As Baar’ur heals, his visits become a mix of social and business.

Healer Che scowls the first time Senator Organa enters with a bag full of datachips, but Baar’ur waves away her frown. “I am needed,” he says, and the words have a weight that Cody doesn’t understand, but Healer Che does, because her frown eases into something sad.

“You may conduct office hours, in here, for a limited time each day,” Healer Che says. “All visits can be ended at my discretion.” Her gaze sharpens as Baar’ur opens his mouth. “This is non-negotiable.”

Cody’s stunned for a moment, and then he laughs. It surprises him as much as it surprises Baar’ur and Senator Organa and Healer Che, but he can’t stop. When he finally wipes the tears from his eyes, he looks over at Healer Che. “You are his Jetii’buir. He learned it from you.”

“Only the good things,” Baar’ur says, and he’s smiling now as well. He takes one of Senator Organa’s datareaders. “Once I’m cleared to drink, buy me a Corellian brandy, and I’ll tell you how The Negotiator got its name.”

“This promises to be a good story,” Senator Organa says.

#

The citizenship bill passes. Cody watches the vote from Baar’ur’s room with Baar’ur and a woman he doesn’t know. She strode in this morning in full beskar’gam, sat at Baar’ur’s side, and hasn’t budged.

She took her helmet off to reveal short-cropped blond hair, but she didn’t introduce herself. Baar’ur didn’t introduce her either, too busy watching the votes tallied.

The citizenship vote passes by a wide margin. The reparations bill is closer, but it passes as well.

Baar’ur leans back against his med-bed with a sigh. “No need for Plan B, then.”

“Good,” the woman says.

Cody looks between them and wonders what he’s missing.

“Ah, where are my manners?” Baar’ur asks. He gestures between Cody and the woman. “Cody, this is Arla Fett. Arla Fett, this is Cody.”

Cody keeps his expression neutral. This is the Prime’s vod. The Prime didn’t think of the vode as his ade. He had Boba. The rest of them were…product. He sold them in exchange for Boba and enough credits to do anything he could possibly want. The vode are vode, but they aren’t part of Clan Fett. He doesn’t know what that makes Arla Fett to him.

“I am Mand’alor,” Arla says. “Plan B was mass adoption. It would legitimize you and your brothers, and I would have done it. But it’s impersonal.” She leans forward and makes sure she has Cody’s full attention. “Any and all of you are welcome in the Mandalorian system. Anyone who wants to join Clan Fett, I will name you as aliit.”

Cody glances at Baar’ur. First, the citizenship bill. And then the reparations bill. And now an offer of family, of a home. He and his vode were made for the Jedi and bred for the war. But the war is over.

Baar’ur misinterprets the look, because he sits up straighter. He can’t quite hide his wince, but he’s stubborn and bats Cody’s hands away when Cody tries to make him more comfortable. “Boba is with her. She took him in after Geonosis. There is a place for all of you. For any who want it.”

“Thank you,” Cody says, his words for Arla, but he doesn’t look away from Baar’ur. “I’ll let the vode know.”

“If possible, I’d like to address them as well,” Arla says. “Jango…I didn’t really know him. We were farmers, and he was annoying but like all brothers are. And then Kyr’stad attacked. I never saw him again. What he did wasn’t right, but he’s dead. His sins are my sins, and I will see this through. A homestead, citizenship, family, whatever you and your vode,” she smiles at the Mando’a word, “want. I will see it done. On my honor as Mand’alor.”

Cody feels a vague stirring, a long-buried pride. Is that something the Prime taught them when they were on Kamino? Or is it something different? The manda that supposedly binds them all together?

“Thank you,” Cody says again. “This is Wolffe’s comm. He’ll set up an audience for you.”

“Not you?” Arla asks.

“I’m needed here,” Cody says.

Arla glances at Baar’ur and then smiles. “I see. Once he’s cleared, you should come visit. Keldabe is thriving.”

“The market is quite lovely,” Baar’ur says.

“We’ve added Jaster’s statue to the Great Hall,” Arla says.

Cody nods. There is an entire history in that city, on that planet. He isn’t sure if he wants it to be his history, but the option is there. He knows he’ll go to see, because he has choices now, and he wants to explore them all.

“Baar’ur can give you the tour,” Arla says. She laughs at the twin looks of surprise she receives. “You think you were the first to look at him and see mandokar?” She shakes her head at Cody. “Now, you really need to visit. I’ll tell you all about when I first met him.”

“This is hardly necessary,” Baar’ur says.

“You could tell me yourself,” Cody ventures, feeling brave.

“He’s over-modest,” Arla says. She ruffles Baar’ur’s hair. “Glad you finally snipped the stupid braid.” Her touch turns gentle. “And I’m glad you pulled through. There’s a place on Mandalore for you too.”

Baar’ur turns to smile at Arla, something soft and private, and Cody feels as though he’s intruding on a moment.

“Thank you,” Baar’ur says. “I would like to visit, at least. It’s difficult to get a good tiingular outside of the Mandalorian system.”

Arla lingers for a moment longer before she takes her leave.

#

Finally, Baar’ur is cleared to leave medical.

He’s accumulated quite the collection of stuff. Crap, as General Skywalker gleefully calls it. Cody helps Baar’ur pack his things carefully into a bag or crate, depending on the item. There are clothes, loose fitting and comfortable, but infinitely superior to med-gowns. There are hygiene items; toothbrush, toothpaste, comb, brush, beard trimmer, and half a dozen more.

There are trinkets. A collection of small stones from Jedi who returned from a mission with a rock or pebble. A wooden figurine one of the generals carved in their downtime. Windchimes from Senator Organa and an ultrasound of the twins from Senator Amidala.

There are dozens of items, large and small, more than Baar’ur ever accumulated in his quarters on The Negotiator. From his slight alarm as they pack, Cody suspects it’s more than he’s ever had period.

Cody carefully wraps a caf mug that says I run on caffeine and sass in stylized script. He places it alongside three other mugs in the crate.

Once they’re finished packing, the room seems bare, sterile in a way it hasn’t in quite some time. Cody’s only comfort is that Baar’ur won’t return here. This isn’t his room. The things they packed, the personal touches, those will go with Baar’ur, whether it’s to his room in the Temple or maybe even Mandalore.

Cody still isn’t sure what to make of Arla Fett. He’s curious enough that he wants to visit Mandalore, see its planets for himself, but he isn’t sure yet if it will be home. He has a suspicion, one so new, so daring, that he carefully guards it, that home for him isn’t a place.

It’s a person.

“Well.” Baar’ur looks around the room. His bag is slung over his shoulder, the crate left for Cody. “I can’t say I’m upset to close the door on this room. But I am grateful for everything it did and what it means."

"There's one final thing," Cody says, and he relishes the curiosity on Baar'ur's face and then his surprise as Cody holds out a jar of lollipops. “Regs say when you leave medical, you take a lollipop.”

“Do they?” Baar’ur asks. His eyes, brighter than they have been recently, twinkle with amusement.

“Non-negotiable,” Cody says, somehow managing to keep a straight face.

Baar’ur laughs and plucks a sweet from the jar. “I know better than to argue with you, dear Cody.”

Dear Cody. He likes it. He holds his free hand out to Baar’ur. “Where to?”

“Wherever we want, I suppose.”

Baar’ur grasps Cody’s hand, and they leave the Halls of Healing together.
